(company)")[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-291) |\n\nSymbols\n-------\n\n### Mascot\n\nMain article: [La\'eeb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La%27eeb "La\'eeb")\n\nThe tournament\'s [official mascot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_mascot "FIFA World Cup mascot") was unveiled on 1 April 2022, during the group stage draw. Its name is "Laʼeeb" ([Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): لعيب, [romanised](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic "Romanization of Arabic"):_Laʿīb_), which is an Arabic word meaning "super-skilled player". The official website of FIFA says: "Laʼeeb will be known for his youthful spirit; spreading joy and confidence everywhere he goes", and the official backstory of the character, published there, claims that it comes from a parallel world where tournament mascots live, "a world where ideas and creativity form the basis of characters that live in the minds of everyone".[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-292)\n\n### Match balls\n\nMain article: [Adidas Al Rihla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adidas_Al_Rihla "Adidas Al Rihla")\n\n[![Image 705](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Al-Rihla_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Al-Rihla_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Al-Rihla_(cropped).jpg)\n\nAdidas Al Rihla\n\n[![Image 706](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Predio_Deportivo_Lionel_Andr%C3%A9s_Messi_-_BugWarp_04_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Predio_Deportivo_Lionel_Andr%C3%A9s_Messi_-_BugWarp_04_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Predio_Deportivo_Lionel_Andr%C3%A9s_Messi_-_BugWarp_04_(cropped).jpg)\n\nAdidas Al Hilm\n\nThe first official match ball, "[Adidas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adidas "Adidas") Al Rihla", was unveiled on 30 March 2022. It was mainly inspired by the culture, architecture, iconic boats and flag of Qatar. In Arabic, the word _Al-Rihla_ (الْرِّحْلَة _ar-riḥla_) means "the journey". The ball was designed with sustainability as a priority, making it the first-ever official match ball created with water-based glues and inks. As "the game is getting faster" and "speeds up", the ball has internal electronic sensors, allowing detection of its speed and position, updated 500 times per second[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-293) and it has to be charged before each game.[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-294) Two of the match balls were sent and returned from space by FIFA and [Qatar Airways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qatar_Airways "Qatar Airways") on a [SpaceX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX")[falcon 9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falcon_9 "Falcon 9")[suborbital mission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sub-orbital_spaceflight "Sub-orbital spaceflight") for promoting the World Cup.[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-295)\n\nThe match ball for the [Semifinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "2022 FIFA World Cup knockout stage"), [Third place play-off](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "2022 FIFA World Cup knockout stage") and [Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2022 FIFA World Cup Final") was announced on 11 December 2022. It is a variation of the Al Rihla named the "Adidas Al Hilm _"_ ([Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): الحلم, [romanised](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic "Romanization of Arabic"):_al-ḥulm_, [lit.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literal_translation "Literal translation")\'\'the dream\'\', a reference to "every nation\'s dream of lifting the FIFA World Cup").[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-296) While the technical aspects of the ball are the same, the colour is different from the Al Rihla balls used in the group stages and preceding knockout games, with a _Gold Metallic_, maroon, _Collegiate Burgundy_, and red design,[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-297) a reference to the [national colours](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Qatar "Flag of Qatar") of host nation [Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qatar "Qatar") and the golden colours shared by the Final\'s [venue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lusail_Stadium "Lusail Stadium") and the [FIFA World Cup Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy "FIFA World Cup Trophy").[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-2022-03-30-fifa-298)\n\n### Music\n\nSee also: [FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 Official Soundtrack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Qatar_2022_Official_Soundtrack "FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 Official Soundtrack") and [List of FIFA World Cup songs and anthems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_songs_and_anthems "List of FIFA World Cup songs and anthems")\n\nFor the first time, a multi-song FIFA World Cup official soundtrack has been released, instead of one official song.[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-299) The first song of the album is "[Hayya Hayya (Better Together)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hayya_Hayya_(Better_Together) "Hayya Hayya (Better Together)")", performed by [Trinidad Cardona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinidad_Cardona "Trinidad Cardona"), [Davido](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davido "Davido"), and AISHA, released on 1 April 2022 along with the music video.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-300) The second song is "Arhbo", performed by [Gims](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gims "Gims") and [Ozuna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ozuna "Ozuna"), released on 19 August 2022 along with the music video.[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-301) The third song is "The World Is Yours to Take" performed by American rapper [Lil Baby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lil_Baby "Lil Baby"), released on 23 September 2022 along with a music video.[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-302) The fourth song is "Light The Sky" performed by [Nora Fatehi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nora_Fatehi "Nora Fatehi"), [Manal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manal_(singer) "Manal (singer)"), [Rahma Riad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rahma_Riad "Rahma Riad"), and [Balqees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balqees_(singer) "Balqees (singer)"), composed by [RedOne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RedOne "RedOne") and released on 7 October 2022 along with the music video.[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-303) A fifth song, "[Tukoh Taka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tukoh_Taka "Tukoh Taka")", performed by [Nicki Minaj](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicki_Minaj "Nicki Minaj"), [Maluma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maluma "Maluma") and [Myriam Fares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myriam_Fares "Myriam Fares"), was released on 17 November 2022 along with the music video, serving as the official song of the [FIFA Fan Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA_Fan_Festival "FIFA Fan Festival").[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-304) The final song is "[Dreamers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dreamers_(Jungkook_song) "Dreamers (Jungkook song)")" by [Jungkook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jungkook "Jungkook") of [BTS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BTS "BTS") released on 20 November 2022. It was performed with [Fahad Al-Kubaisi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fahad_Al-Kubaisi "Fahad Al-Kubaisi") during the tournament\'s opening ceremony.[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-305)[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-306)\n\nControversies\n-------------\n\nMain article: [List of 2022 FIFA World Cup controversies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2022_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies "List of 2022 FIFA World Cup controversies")\n\nCriticism of the 2022 FIFA World Cup focused on Qatar\'s [human-rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_Qatar "Human rights in Qatar") record,[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-foreignpolicy3-307) namely their [treatment of migrant workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Human_rights_concern "2022 FIFA World Cup controversies"),[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-foreignpolicy3-307)[women](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#Controversies#Women\'s_rights), and [position on LGBT rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Qatar "LGBT rights in Qatar"),[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-JPost_2022-308) leading to allegations of [sportswashing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sportswashing "Sportswashing").[[F]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-312) Others cited Qatar\'s climate, [lack of a strong football culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Match_incidents "2022 FIFA World Cup controversies"), and allegations of bribery for hosting rights and [wider FIFA corruption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_FIFA_corruption_case "2015 FIFA corruption case").[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Reason_2022-9)[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Atlantic_20222-313)[Boycotts of the event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Boycotts "2022 FIFA World Cup controversies") were declared by several countries, clubs, and individual players,[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Dhaka_2022-310)[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Comercio_2022-311) with former FIFA president [Sepp Blatter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter") twice stating that giving Qatar hosting rights was a "mistake".[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-314)[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-315) The FIFA World Cup delivered record-breaking numbers of TV audiences across multiple markets.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-316) In June 2023, _[Le Point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le\\_Point "Le Point")_ revealed that FIFA World Cup has raised great interest in the country despite "calls for a [boycott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boycott "Boycott")". According to the study by _Arcom_, six out of ten French people followed at least one match.[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-317)\n\n### Host selection criticism\n\nThere have been allegations of bribery and corruption in the selection process involving FIFA\'s executive committee members.[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-318) These allegations are being investigated by FIFA (see [§Bidding corruption allegations, 2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#Bidding_corruption_allegations,_2014), below). In May 2011, allegations of corruption within the FIFA senior officials raised questions over the legitimacy of the World Cup 2022 being held in Qatar. The accusations of corruption were made relating to how Qatar won the right to host the event. A FIFA internal investigation and report cleared Qatar of any violation, but chief investigator [Michael J. Garcia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_J._Garcia "Michael J. Garcia") described FIFA\'s report on his enquiry as containing "numerous materially incomplete and erroneous representations."[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-319)\n\nIn May 2015, Swiss federal prosecutors [opened an investigation into corruption and money laundering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_FIFA_corruption_case "2015 FIFA corruption case") related to the [2018 and 2022 World Cup bids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_and_2022_FIFA_World_Cup_bids "2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids").[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-320)[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-321) In August 2018, former FIFA president [Sepp Blatter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter") claimed that Qatar had used "black ops", suggesting that the bid committee had cheated to win the hosting rights.[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-322) Some investigations found that Qatar sought an edge in securing hosting by hiring a former [CIA officer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency "Central Intelligence Agency") turned private contractor, Kevin Chalker, to spy on rival bid teams and key football officials who picked the winner in 2010.[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-323)\n\nIn September 2018, a delegation from al-Ghufran tribe lodged a complaint to FIFA\'s president to reject the establishment of the World Cup in Qatar unless its government restored the Qatari nationality to all those affected from the tribe and returned land allegedly stolen from them to build the sport facilities.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-324)\n\nIn September 2023 it was reported that court documents show a transfer of $300M dollars were sent top people who voted on the 2022 World Cup host.[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-325)\n\nQatar faced strong criticism for the treatment of foreign workers involved in preparation for the World Cup, with [Amnesty International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International "Amnesty International") referring to "forced labour" and poor working conditions,[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-326)[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-327) while many migrant workers reported having to pay large "recruitment fees" to obtain employment.[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-guardian-workers-pay-328)_[The Guardian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\\_Guardian "The Guardian")_ newspaper reported that many workers were denied food and water, had their identity papers taken away from them, and that they were not paid on time or at all, making some of them in effect slaves. _The Guardian_ estimated that up to 4,000 workers could die from lax safety and other causes by the time the competition was held. Between 2015 and 2021, the [Qatari government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Qatar "Government of Qatar") adopted new labour reforms to improve working conditions, including a minimum wage for all workers and the removal of the [kafala system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kafala_system "Kafala system"). Furthermore, in November 2017, the [International Labour Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Labour_Organization "International Labour Organization") concluded that no rights were violated and made the decision to close the complaint against Qatar regarding the alleged violation of migrant workers\' rights.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-329) According to Amnesty International, however, living and working conditions of the foreign workers did not improve in the last years.[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-330)\n\nQatar was the smallest nation by area ever to have been awarded a FIFA World Cup– the next smallest by area was Switzerland, host of the [1954 World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1954_FIFA_World_Cup "1954 FIFA World Cup"), which was more than three times as large as Qatar and only needed to host 16 teams instead of 32. Qatar also became only the second country (not including Uruguay and Italy, hosts of the first two World Cups) to be awarded a FIFA World Cup despite having never qualified for a previous edition: Japan was awarded co-hosting rights of the [2002 World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") in 1996 without ever having qualified for the finals, although they qualified for the [1998 edition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup"). Of the eight stadiums used in the tournament, six were located in the [Doha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doha "Doha")[metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doha_Metropolitan_Area "Doha Metropolitan Area"), making it the first World Cup [since 1930](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup "1930 FIFA World Cup") in which most of the stadiums were in one city. While this decreased the distance that fans and players needed to commute, Qatar itself struggled to accommodate the numbers of arriving fans with its diminutive amount of space.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-331)\n\nDue to Qatar\'s [laws on alcohol consumption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_with_alcohol_prohibition "List of countries with alcohol prohibition"), World Cup organisers announced the creation of designated "sobering-up" zones as an alternative to wide-scale arrests of intoxicated fans during the World Cup.[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-332) Qatar\'s World Cup chief executive of the Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy, Nasser Al Khater, stated that the purpose of the designated sobering-up areas was to ensure the fans\' safety.[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-333) If a fan was sent to the "sobering up" zone, they were permitted to leave when they could display clearheaded behaviour.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-334) Multiple news agencies described the controversy as a "cultural clash" between [social conservatism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_conservatism "Social conservatism") and [Islamic morality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morality_in_Islam "Morality in Islam") against the "norms" of [secular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secularity "Secularity") Western [liberal democracies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_democracy "Liberal democracy").[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:0-14)[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:2-335)\n\nA number of groups and media outlets expressed concern over the suitability of Qatar to host the event.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-336)[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-guardian-337) Issues regarding from [human rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_Qatar "Human rights in Qatar"),[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-foreignpolicy-11)[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-JPost_2022-308) worker conditions, the rights of [LGBT fans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_community "LGBT community"),[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-JPost_2022-308) and the [illegality of homosexuality in Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Qatar "LGBT rights in Qatar").[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-338)[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-339)[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-340) In December 2020, Qatar said [rainbow flags](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainbow_flag_(LGBT) "Rainbow flag (LGBT)") would be allowed at the 2022 FIFA World Cup.[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-341) Qatari officials initially stated that they would not prohibit the display of [pride flags](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pride_flag "Pride flag") at tournament venues, although the country still advised LGBT attendees to comply with the country\'s [modesty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modesty "Modesty") and avoid [public displays of affection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_display_of_affection "Public display of affection").[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:3-342)[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:4-343) Hassan Abdulla al-Thawadi, chief executive of the country\'s World Cup bid, said that Qatar would permit [alcohol consumption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcohol_consumption "Alcohol consumption") during the event,[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-344)[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-sportsgrid-345) even though [drinking in public](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drinking_in_public "Drinking in public") was not permitted.[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-346) There were plans to allow the sale of alcohol inside stadiums and at fan villages.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-BBC_Sport-347) Normally, the sale of alcohol is restricted to non-Muslim guests at selected luxury hotels only.[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-wsj201201072-348) However, in the months preceding the tournament, the display of LGBT material and the sale of alcohol were banned.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-BBC_Sport-347)[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:5-349)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:6-350)[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Financial_Times-351)[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Reuters2-352)\n\nThe climate conditions caused some to call hosting the tournament in Qatar infeasible, with initial plans for air-conditioned stadiums giving way to a potential date switch from summer to November and December.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Atlantic_2022-8) In May 2014, [Sepp Blatter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter"), who was FIFA president at the time of the selection, remarked that awarding the World Cup to Qatar was a "mistake" because of the extreme heat.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Atlantic_2022-8)[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-353)[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-354) While addressing delegates from African and Asian confederations, Blatter said allegations of corruption and some of the criticism, including those from sponsors, were "very much linked to racism and discrimination".[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-355) The attendance figures at the matches also came under scrutiny as the reported crowd attendance was more than the stadium capacities despite games having visible empty seats.[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-356)\n\nPrior to the tournament, a reporter for Denmark\'s [TV 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_2_(Denmark) "TV 2 (Denmark)") was threatened by security during a live report from the [Katara Cultural Village](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katara_Cultural_Village "Katara Cultural Village"); the organising committee apologised, stating that they were "mistakenly interrupted".[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-357)[Tony O\'Donoghue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_O%27Donoghue "Tony O\'Donoghue") of Ireland\'s [RTÉ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RT%C3%89 "RTÉ") also accused Qatari police of interrupting him while filming.[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-358)\n\n[Phaedra Almajid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phaedra_Al-Majid "Phaedra Al-Majid"), a former media officer for Qatar\'s 2022 World Cup bid, has alleged that three African football officials were offered bribes to support Qatar\'s bid. In a Netflix documentary series "[FIFA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA "FIFA") Uncovered," Almajid claims that [Hassan Al Thawadi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hassan_Al-Thawadi "Hassan Al-Thawadi"), who led Qatar\'s bid, offered €2.3 million each to [Issa Hayatou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issa_Hayatou "Issa Hayatou") of Cameroon, [Jacques Anouma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Anouma "Jacques Anouma") of Ivory Coast, and [Amos Adamu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amos_Adamu "Amos Adamu") of Nigeria in exchange for their votes. Qatar was competing with Australia, Japan, South Korea and the US for their bid for the 2022 World Cup. The alleged offer was made during a meeting of African football federations in January 2010. Almajid states that the money was intended for the football federations, not as personal bribes. She initially disclosed these allegations anonymously to the [Sunday Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sunday_Times "The Sunday Times") after being dismissed from her position, but later retracted her claims, citing threats from [Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qatar "Qatar"). Al Thawadi has denied these allegations, calling them false and expressing disappointment at the situation. The controversy adds to the ongoing scrutiny surrounding Qatar\'s successful bid to host the 2022 World Cup.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-359)\n\n### Targeted hacking campaigns against critics\n\nOn November 2, 2022, Swiss media outlet SRF Investigativ published an investigative piece about Qatar\'s elaborate and extensive espionage operation to secure the World Cup hosting rights. The operation, which was dubbed Project Merciless, involved hacking emails and phones of FIFA officials and critics of Qatar\'s corruption and [poor human rights record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_Qatar "Human rights in Qatar"). It also targeted their friends and family members to run smear campaigns and influence FIFA policy. Starting on January 5, 2012, a cyberattack targeted Peter Hargitay, a Zurich-based FIFA insider and consultant for Australia\'s 2022 World Cup bid. Hargitay and his son hired an expert who traced the hack to a server linked to Rajat Khare of the mercenary Indian hack-for-hire firm [Appin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appin_(company) "Appin (company)").[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-SRF-2022-11-02-360)[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-ap-qatar-spy-on-fifa-361)[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-io-rajat-khare-helping-qatar-362)[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-st-buy-the-world-cup-363) In November 2022, a lower court in [Geneva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva "Geneva") ordered the publication to provisionally remove Rajat Khare\'s name and photo from the article.[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-rsf-appin-silencing-media-364) As a result, he is currently referred to as an entrepreneur, though his name still appears in a [Reuters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters "Reuters") article about his involvement in the hacking.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-reuters-special-report-appin-365)\n\nOn 5 November 2022, _[The Sunday Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\\_Sunday\\_Times "The Sunday Times")_ and the [Bureau of Investigative Journalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bureau_of_Investigative_Journalism "Bureau of Investigative Journalism") published an investigation reporting that a group from an Indian hacking company had compromised the email accounts of various politicians, reporters, and other prominent individuals that had been critical of Qatar\'s hosting of the World Cup. It was also reported that the group had been hired by Jonas Rey, private investigators based in Switzerland, which were in turn hired by Qatari officials.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-The_Bureau_of_Investigative_Journalism-366)\n\n### Migrant workers\n\nMain article: [Human rights issues involving the 2022 FIFA World Cup §Migrant workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_issues_involving_the_2022_FIFA_World_Cup#Migrant_workers "Human rights issues involving the 2022 FIFA World Cup")\n\nThere was criticism regarding the state of [human rights in Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_Qatar "Human rights in Qatar") and of the conditions of migrant workers brought in to build the required infrastructure, including indentured servitude and working conditions leading to deaths.[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-370) On 23 October 2022, an article published by _[The Guardian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\\_Guardian "The Guardian")_ included statements from migrants working on the event infrastructure. Surveying 1,000 workers, 86% of participants said that the labour changes had improved their lives and that better working conditions are negotiable.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-371) Legislation has also been proposed on the minimum wage, summertime worker safety, and the election of migrant worker representatives in businesses. Labour mobility is a result of changes to the [Kafala system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kafala_system "Kafala system").[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-372)\n\nAccording to [Sharan Burrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharan_Burrow "Sharan Burrow"), general secretary of the International Trade Union Confederation, prior to the tournament, "the new Kafala system tranche of law will put an end to Kafala and establish a contemporary industrial relations system."[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-373)\n\nFIFA President [Gianni Infantino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gianni_Infantino "Gianni Infantino") has defended Qatar\'s decision to host the tournament.[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-374) Others have asserted that Qatar has a better human rights record than [Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia "Russia") and [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China"), which were subjected to less harsh criticism for the same problems when hosting important athletic events in the years before the tournament.[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-375)\n\n### Move to November and December\n\nOwing to the [climate in Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_Qatar "Climate of Qatar"), concerns were expressed over holding the World Cup in its traditional time frame of June and July.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Atlantic_2022-8) In October 2013, a task force was commissioned to consider alternative dates and report after the [2014 FIFA World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup") in Brazil.[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-autogenerated4-376) On 24 February 2015, the FIFA Task Force proposed that the tournament be played from late November to late December 2022,[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-fifa_task_force-377) to avoid the summer heat and also avoid clashing with the [2022 Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics "2022 Winter Olympics") in February, the [2022 Winter Paralympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Winter_Paralympics "2022 Winter Paralympics") in March and [Ramadan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramadan "Ramadan") in April.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-378)[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-379)\n\nThe notion of staging the tournament in November was controversial because it would interfere with the regular season schedules of some domestic leagues around the world. Commentators noted the clash with the Christian Christmas season was likely to cause disruption, while there was concern about how short the tournament was intended to be.[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-380) FIFA executive committee member [Theo Zwanziger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theo_Zwanziger "Theo Zwanziger") said that awarding the event to Qatar was a "blatant mistake".[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-381)\n\n[Frank Lowy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Lowy "Frank Lowy"), chairman of [Football Federation Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_Federation_Australia "Football Federation Australia"), said that if the 2022 World Cup were moved to November and thus upset the schedule of the [A-League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A-League "A-League"), they would seek compensation from FIFA.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-382)[Richard Scudamore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Scudamore "Richard Scudamore"), chief executive of the [Premier League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League"), stated that they would consider legal action against FIFA because a move would interfere with the Premier League\'s popular Christmas and New Year fixture programme.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-383) In 2015, FIFA confirmed that the final would be played in December.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-384) Critics condemned the Euro-centrism of these allegations, and questioned why global sporting events must be held within the traditional European summer season.[[379]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-385)\n\n### Bidding corruption allegations, 2014\n\nSee also: [Garcia Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garcia_Report "Garcia Report")\n\nSome allegations were made over the role of former football official [Mohammed bin Hammam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammed_bin_Hammam "Mohammed bin Hammam") played in securing the bid.[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-386) A former employee of the Qatar bid team alleged that several African officials were paid $1.5 million by Qatar.[[381]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-387) She retracted her claims, but later said that she was coerced to do so by Qatari bid officials.[[382]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-388)[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-389) In March 2014, it was discovered that former [CONCACAF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF") president [Jack Warner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Warner_(football_executive) "Jack Warner (football executive)") and his family were paid almost $2 million from a firm linked to Qatar\'s successful campaign.[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-390)\n\n_[The Sunday Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\\_Sunday\\_Times "The Sunday Times")_ published bribery allegations based on a leak of millions of secret documents.[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-391) Five of FIFA\'s six primary sponsors, [Sony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony "Sony"), [Adidas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adidas "Adidas"), [Visa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc."), [Hyundai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyundai_Motor_Company "Hyundai Motor Company"), and [Coca-Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola"), called upon FIFA to investigate the claims.[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-392)[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-393)[Jim Boyce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Boyce_(football_administrator) "Jim Boyce (football administrator)"), vice-president of FIFA, stated he would support a re-vote to find a new host if the corruption allegations are proven.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-394)[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-395) FIFA completed a lengthy investigation into these allegations and a report cleared Qatar of any wrongdoing. Despite the claims, the Qataris insisted that the corruption allegations were being driven by envy and mistrust while Blatter said it was fuelled by racism in the British media.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-396)[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-397)\n\nIn the [2015 FIFA corruption case](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_FIFA_corruption_case "2015 FIFA corruption case"), Swiss officials, operating under information from the [United States Department of Justice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department of Justice"), arrested many senior FIFA officials in Zürich and seized physical and electronic records from FIFA\'s main headquarters. The arrests continued in the United States, where several FIFA officers were arrested, and FIFA buildings were raided. The arrests were made on the information of at least a $150 million corruption and bribery scandal.[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-398) From those arrested, $40 million was forfeited under guilty pleas.[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Justice_Dept-399) In 2022, the president of the El Salvador soccer association, Reynaldo Vasquez, was sentenced to 16 months in prison in connection to over $350,000 in bribes.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-400)\n\nFollowing the corruption case, Phaedra Almajid, the former media officer for the Qatar bid team, claimed that the allegations would result in Qatar not hosting the World Cup.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-401) In an interview published on the same day, [Domenico Scala](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domenico_Scala_(manager) "Domenico Scala (manager)"), the head of FIFA\'s Audit and Compliance Committee, stated that "should there be evidence that the awards to Qatar and Russia came only because of bought votes, then the awards could be cancelled."[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-BBC_News-402)[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Owen_Gibson-403)\n\nIn 2014, FIFA appointed Michael Garcia as its independent ethics investigator to look into bribery allegations against Russia and Qatar. Garcia investigated all nine bids and eleven countries involved in the 2018 and 2022 bids.[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-404) At the end of the investigation, Garcia submitted a 430-page report. The FIFA governing body then appointed a German judge, Hans Joachim Eckert, who reviewed and presented a 42-page summary of the report two months later. The report cleared Qatar and Russia of bribery allegations, stating that Qatar "pulled Aspire into the orbit of the bid in significant ways" but did not "compromise the integrity" of the overall bid process.[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-BBC-405) Michael Garcia reacted almost immediately, stating that the report is "materially incomplete" and contains "erroneous representations of the facts and conclusions".[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-BBC-405)\n\nIn 2017, a German journalist Peter Rossberg claimed to have obtained the report and wrote that it "does not provide proof that the 2018 or 2022 World Cup was bought" and stated that he would publish the full report. This forced FIFA to release the original report. The full report did not provide any evidence of corruption against the host of the 2022 World Cup but stated that bidders tested the rules of conduct to the limit.[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-406)\n\n### Russian participation\n\nOn 9 December 2019, the [World Anti-Doping Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Anti-Doping_Agency "World Anti-Doping Agency") (WADA) handed Russia a four-year ban from all major sporting events, after [RUSADA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Anti-Doping_Agency "Russian Anti-Doping Agency") was found non-compliant for handing over manipulated lab data to investigators.[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-407) The [Russian national team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia_national_football_team "Russia national football team") were still permitted to enter qualification, as the ban only applied to the final tournament to decide the world champions. A team representing Russia, which used the [Russian flag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Russia "Flag of Russia") and [anthem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_anthem_of_Russia "National anthem of Russia"), could not participate under the WADA decision whilst the ban was active.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-408) The decision was appealed to the [Court of Arbitration for Sport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Court_of_Arbitration_for_Sport "Court of Arbitration for Sport"),[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-409) and on 17 December 2020, Russian teams were banned from competing at world championships organised or sanctioned by a WADA signatory until 16 December 2022, the day before the third place play-off.[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-410)\n\nAfter the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine"), Russia\'s participation was further thrown into doubt. On 24 February 2022, the three teams in Russia\'s [qualifying path](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_second_round "2022 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA second round")—[Czech Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czech_Republic_national_football_team "Czech Republic national football team"), [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland_national_football_team "Poland national football team"), and [Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweden_men%27s_national_football_team "Sweden men\'s national football team")—announced their unwillingness to play any matches in Russian territory.[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-411) Poland and Sweden extended the boycott on 26 February to any qualifying games, and the Czech Republic made the same decision one day later.[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-412)[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-413)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-414)\n\nOn 27 February 2022, FIFA announced a number of sanctions impacting Russia\'s participation in international football. Russia was prohibited from hosting international competitions, and the national team was ordered to play all home matches [behind closed doors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behind_closed_doors_(sport) "Behind closed doors (sport)") in neutral countries. Under these sanctions, Russia would not be allowed to compete under the country\'s name, flag, or national anthem; similarly to the Russian athletes\' participation in events such as the Olympics,[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-415) the team would compete under the abbreviation of their national federation, the [Russian Football Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Football_Union "Russian Football Union") ("RFU"), rather than "Russia".[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-416) The next day, FIFA decided to suspend Russia from international competitions "until further notice", including its participation in the 2022 FIFA World Cup.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-417)\n\n### LGBT and women\'s rights\n\nMain article: [LGBT issues at the 2022 FIFA World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_issues_at_the_2022_FIFA_World_Cup "LGBT issues at the 2022 FIFA World Cup")\n\nThere are no [LGBT rights in Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Qatar "LGBT rights in Qatar"), with homosexuality as well as campaigning for [LGBTQ+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBTQ%2B "LGBTQ+") rights criminalised. As such, when Qatar was selected to host the 2022 FIFA World Cup, the choice to do so in a restrictive nation saw much criticism, with the security of fans,[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-418) as well as the homophobic football chants of certain nations, were points of discussion.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-419) The main controversy came from a last-minute FIFA decision to hand out player punishments to European captains who had months earlier announced their intention to continue wearing rainbow-coloured armbands (which began in 2020) in support of anti-discrimination. Typically, kit violations incur a fine, which the teams had said they would pay; on the day of the first match involving one of the teams, FIFA reportedly told the teams that they would receive a yellow card at a minimum for wearing the armbands.[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Denmark_ready_to_lead_European_withdrawal_from_FIFA_over_armband_row-420) Qatari officials stated that all people are welcome as long as they follow the public display of affection laws which apply to everyone.[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-421)[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-422)\n\nSecurity officials at stadiums also confiscated items of rainbow clothing and flags featuring rainbows.[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Qatar_insists_rainbow_colours_are_allowed_at_World_Cup_after_%E2%80%98localised_incidents%E2%80%99_|_The_Independent-423)[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-CNN_11-28-2022-424) American journalist [Grant Wahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_Wahl "Grant Wahl") was briefly detained for wearing a t-shirt with a rainbow on it.[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-425) Wahl reportedly received death threats for wearing the shirt, later dying at the stadium.[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-426)[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-427) Other journalists with Wahl at the time of his death have reported that he began fitting or experiencing a seizure, and called for help himself. They criticised the Qatar Supreme Committee for not providing [defibrillators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defibrillator "Defibrillator") in the stadium, as they had looked for one to try to help Wahl.[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-428) In response, FIFA said that according to the ambulance service, a defibrillator was made available when paramedics later arrived on scene.[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-429) An autopsy done on Wahl in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") later revealed that Wahl died from an [aortic aneurysm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aortic_aneurysm "Aortic aneurysm") rupture.[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-430)\n\nDiscrimination against women in Qatar was also criticised.[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-FIFI_World_Cup_Qatar_Controversial_Host-431)[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-432)[Women in Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women_in_Qatar "Women in Qatar") have few freedoms,[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-FIFI_World_Cup_Qatar_Controversial_Host-431)[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-433) as they must obtain permission from their male guardians to marry, study abroad on government scholarships, work in many government jobs, travel abroad, receive certain forms of reproductive health care, and act as the primary guardian of children, even if they are divorced.[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-434)\n\nQatar attracted particular criticism for an incident where a Mexican employee of the World Cup Organizing Committee was accused of allegedly having [sex outside of marriage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zina "Zina"). The woman had previously reported rape, while the male claimed to have been in a relationship with her, after which the woman was investigated for extramarital sex. Women in Qatar face the possible penalty of [flagellation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flagellation "Flagellation") and a seven-year prison sentence if convicted for having sex outside of marriage. The criminal case was eventually dropped months after she was allowed to leave Qatar.[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-435)\n\n### Influence of Iran\n\n[![Image 707](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Iran_national_team_fan_01.jpg/250px-Iran_national_team_fan_01.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Iran_national_team_fan_01.jpg)\n\nAn Iranian fan showing a banner with "[Woman, Life, Freedom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woman,_Life,_Freedom "Woman, Life, Freedom")" slogan.\n\nIn November 2022, there were reports suggesting that the government of [Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran "Iran") were working with Qatari officials to suppress anti-government protests at the 2022 FIFA World Cup,[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-auto7-436) in light of the [Mahsa Amini protests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahsa_Amini_protests "Mahsa Amini protests"). Leaked documents and audio clips suggested that Iranian government officials were in correspondence with Qatari authorities in order to handle possible protesters.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-437)\n\nIn November 2022, the Qatari government revoked the visas of journalists from a London-based Iranian news channel, [Iran International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran_International "Iran International"), known for being critical of the regime, who were seeking to cover the World Cup.[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-438) On 21 November 2022, during the first group stage match from Group B, between Iran and England, attempts were reportedly made by the stadium\'s security forces to block Iranian fans who wore clothing or carried items bearing slogans that were deemed unsympathetic to the Islamic government of Iran.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-439) These included t-shirts and signs with "[Woman, Life, Freedom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woman,_Life,_Freedom "Woman, Life, Freedom")" embedded onto them, Iran\'s previous flags, or any slogans containing the name of [Mahsa Amini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_of_Mahsa_Amini "Death of Mahsa Amini").[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-440) This crackdown continued throughout all of Iran\'s matches at the World Cup.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-auto7-436) In addition to removing fans from stadiums, reports showed that officials tried to suppress any filming or photography of possible protests. In one case, Qatari police detained Danish TV presenter, Rasmus Tantholdt, for filming fans with "Woman, Life, Freedom" slogans, some of whom who had been earlier abused by a group of pro-government supporters.[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-441)\n\n### Treatment of Jewish and Israeli visitors\n\nQatar had previously promised to provide Jewish tourists with cooked [_kosher_ food](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kashrut "Kashrut") and public [Jewish prayer services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prayer_in_Judaism "Prayer in Judaism") at the tournament. However, shortly before the World Cup began, both were banned by Qatar, who claimed it could not secure the safety of Jews.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-442)[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-443) Qatar alleged that they could not "secure" the safety of publicly praying Jewish tourists, whilst many foreign Jews complained that they subsequently had no food available to eat. It was estimated that 10,000 [religious Jews from Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israeli_Jews "Israeli Jews") and around the world arrived to watch the World Cup in Qatar.[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:23-444)\n\nWhilst Jewish organisations complained of being unable to find cooked kosher food,[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-:23-444) the [Israeli government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Israel "Government of Israel") said it was happy with the efforts made by Qatar to meet its requests, including kosher food, direct flights from Israel to Qatar, and temporary diplomatic representation in the country. A kosher kitchen under the supervision of Rabbi [Mendy Chitrik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mendy_Chitrik "Mendy Chitrik") was open in time for the first match. Rabbi [Marc Schneier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Schneier "Marc Schneier"), president of [The Foundation for Ethnic Understanding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Foundation_for_Ethnic_Understanding "The Foundation for Ethnic Understanding"), said he had never asked the Qatari government for cooked food, and he had been the only person in communication with the Qataris regarding making the World Cup experience inclusive for Jews.[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-445)\n\nMultiple Israeli reporters at the tournament reported fans from [Arab nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_world "Arab world") waving [Palestinian flags](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Palestine "Flag of Palestine") and chanting [anti-Israeli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criticism_of_Israel "Criticism of Israel") slogans while harassing them.[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-JPost_2022-308)[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-merged1-446)[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-447) Some Israelis reported that they had been escorted out of restaurants when their nationality was revealed.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-448) The Israeli government warned its citizens traveling to the tournament to hide their Israeli identity out of safety concerns.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-449)\n\n### Accommodation\n\nThe [Rawdat Al Jahhaniya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rawdat_Al_Jahhaniya "Rawdat Al Jahhaniya") fan village was criticised for its overpriced "night cabins" (£185 per night) made out of shipping containers. Tourists complained that the air conditioners in the cabins did not function well, facilities were falling apart, and the sleeping experience did not match their expectations.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-450) The BBC reported that the tent accommodation at the Qetaifan Island fan village got criticism for having brown-coloured tap water and no air conditioning other than a standing fan.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-451)[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-452) The tent village in [Al Khor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Khor "Al Khor") was criticised for having inconvenient transportation, a lack of alcohol, long waits to check in, and no locks on the tents.[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-453)[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-454) The lack of suitable and affordable accommodation raised demand for daily shuttle flights from neighbouring areas, such as Dubai, that had adequate numbers of hotel rooms.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-455)\n\nSecurity\n--------\n\n[![Image 708: [icon]](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg)This section **needs expansion**. request](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3A2022_FIFA_World_Cup&preload=Template%3ASubmit+an+edit+request%2Fpreload&action=edit&section=new&editintro=Template%3AEdit+protected%2Feditintro&preloadtitle=Protected+edit+request+on+6+October+2025&preloadparams%5B%5D=edit+fully-protected&preloadparams%5B%5D=2022+FIFA+World+Cup)[adding to it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2022_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=). _(August 2024)_\n\nThe Qatari government employed about 50,000 security personnel including police departments and military forces from at least thirteen countries, including Poland, Germany, France, Kuwait, Jordan, Italy, Palestine, Spain, Pakistan, Turkey, USA, Saudi Arabia and the United Kingdom.[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Qatar-456)[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-457)\n\n### Turkey\n\nTurkey provided about 3,000 riot police personnel.[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Qatar-456)\n\n### Pakistan\n\nPakistan provided about 4,500 Army troops to Qatar for the event.[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-458)\n\nSee also\n--------\n\n*   [FIFA World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup")\n*   [FIFA World Cup hosts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts "FIFA World Cup hosts")\n*   [2021 FIFA Arab Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_FIFA_Arab_Cup "2021 FIFA Arab Cup")\n*   [2023 FIFA Women\'s World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "2023 FIFA Women\'s World Cup")\n\nNotes\n-----\n\n1. [Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia "Russia"), also featured one or two Asian venues depending on definition for [the intercontinental boundary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boundary_between_Asia_and_Europe "Boundary between Asia and Europe").\n2. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_ref-312)**Citations:[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Atlantic_2022-8)[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-anandabazar-309)[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Dhaka_2022-310)[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup#cite_note-Comercio_2022-311)\n\nReferences\n----------\n\n1. "# The Best FIFA Football Awards™ 2022 - All the winners\n\nPublished\n\nLionel Messi and Alexia Putellas were two of the winners on a star-studded night in Paris\n\n* Messi takes home the men’s player award following historic FIFA World Cup™ victory\n* Barcelona and Spain midfielder Putellas claims the award for The Best women's player\n* Earps, Martinez, Wiegman, Scaloni and Oleksy among other winners.\n\nThe Best FIFA Football Awards 2022™ ceremony in Paris crowned Alexia Putellas and Lionel Messi as the outstanding players of the past year, alongside recognising the performances of coaches, goalkeepers and more across the men’s and women’s game.\n\nMary Earps was voted The Best FIFA Women’s Goalkeeper after in a year in which she lifted the UEFA Women’s EURO 2022 with the Lionesses. Argentina shot-stopper Emiliano Martínez got his hands on The Best FIFA Men’s Goalkeeper prize following his outstanding performances throughout FIFA World Cup 2022.\n\nEngland manager Sarina Wiegman won The Best FIFA Women’s Coach after leading the Lionesses to European glory and her second successive UEFA EURO title, while Argentina boss Lionel Scaloni added The Best FIFA Men’s Coach to his trophy cabinet, alongside the FIFA World Cup trophy.\nThe Best FIFA Football Awards ceremony also recognised the standout goal of the year as Marcin Oleksy won The FIFA Puskás Award for his impressive finish.\n\nGeorgian player Luka Lochoshvili picked up The FIFA Fair Play Award in recognition of his exemplary reaction whilst playing for Wolfsberger AC when an opposing player fell unconscious on the pitch and Luka rushed to his aid.\n\nIn addition, Argentinian fans were recognised for their support of the national team during the FIFA World Cup 2022, which saw impressive numbers travel to Qatar and millions of fans then welcomed their winning heroes home to Buenos Aires and across the country.\n\n## The winners of The Best FIFA Football Awards 2022: The winners of The Best FIFA Football Awards 2022:\n\n[The Best FIFA Women's Player: Alexia Putellas](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/putellas-wins-best-fifa-womens-player-award-for-second-year-running-mead-morgan)\n[The Best FIFA Men's Player: Lionel Messi](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/lionel-messi-wins-the-best-fifa-mens-player-award-mbappe-benzema)\n[The Best FIFA Women's Coach: Sarina Wiegman](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/england-boss-wiegman-wins-the-best-fifa-womens-coach-award-bompastor-sundhage)\n[The Best FIFA Men's Coach: Lionel Scaloni](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/scaloni-honoured-with-best-fifa-mens-coach-award-ancelotti-guardiola)\n[The Best FIFA Women's Goalkeeper:\ufeff Mary Earps](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/earps-wins-the-best-fifa-womens-goalkeeper-award-berger-endler)\n[The Best FIFA Men's Goalkeeper: Emiliano Martinez](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/tbffa-2022-the-best-fifa-mens-goalkeeper-martinez-bounou-courtois)\n[The FIFA Puskás Award: Marcin Oleksy](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/amputee-footballer-oleksy-wins-fifa-puskas-award-richarlison-payet-the-best)\n[The FIFA Fair Play Award: Luka Lochoshvili](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/fifa-fairplay-winner-revealed-the-best-football-awards-lochoshvili-mane-camavinga)\n[The FIFA Fan Award: Argentinian Fans](https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/articles/argentina-supporters-win-fifa-fan-the-best-fifa-football-awards)\n\n---\n\n## Your Privacy\n\nWe use cookies to personalize content and ads, provide social media features and analyse our traffic. You can select your cookie preferences by clicking on the buttons on the right and place a do not sell or share my personal information request. [Data Protection Portal](https://www.fifa.com/legal/data-protection-portal/)\n\n## Privacy Preference Center\n\n\n\n* ### Your Privacy\n* ### Strictly Necessary Cookies\n* ### Functional Cookies\n* ### Performance Cookies\n* ### Targeting Cookies\n\n#### Your Privacy\n\nWhen you visit any website, it may store or retrieve information on your browser, mostly in the form of cookies. This information might be about you, your preferences or your device and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to. The information does not usually directly identify you, but it can give you a more personalized web experience. Because we respect your right to privacy, you can choose to opt out of some types of cookies. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings. However, opting out of some types of cookies may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Using the link below, you can contact our Data Protection team to place a do not sell or share my personal information request:\n  \n[Do not sell my personal data](mailto:dataprotection@fifa.org)\n\n#### Strictly Necessary Cookies\n\nAlways Active\n\nThese cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. \xa0 \xa0You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.\n\n#### Functional Cookies\n\nInactive\n\nThese cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. \xa0 \xa0If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.\n\n#### Performance Cookies\n\nInactive\n\nThese cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site. \xa0 \xa0All information these cookies collect is aggregated and therefore anonymous. If you do not allow these cookies we will not know when you have visited our site, and will not be able to monitor its performance.", 'images': []}, {'url': 'https://fifpro.org/en/supporting-players/player-influence/player-impact/players-recognised-with-individual-awards-at-2022-world-cup', 'raw_content': '# Players recognised with individual awards at 2022 World Cup\n\n18 December 2022\n\nShare this quote\n\nShare\n\n##### Players recognised with individual awards at 2022 World Cup\n\n18 December 2022\n\n{0} min. reading time\n\n* **Argentina won third World Cup after penalty shoot-out victory against France**\n* **Young Player, Golden Glove, Golden Boot, and Golden Ball awards presented after final**\n* **FIFPRO recaps the winners of the Qatar 2022 player awards**\n\nAfter Argentina claimed their third men’s World Cup crown following a penalty shoot-out victory against France, four players were recognised for their outstanding performances with individual awards.\n\nThe Young Player, Golden Glove, Golden Boot, and Golden Ball awards were all presented before *La Albiceleste* lifted the men’s World Cup trophy –\xa0which closed the curtain on four thrilling weeks of international football. FIFPRO recaps the winners of the player awards at Qatar 2022.\n\n### **Young Player Award: Enzo Fernandez**\n\n**Age**: 21**Position**: Midfielder**Club**: Benfica **Nation**: Argentina\n\nEnzo Fernandez was crowned the best young player at Qatar 2022. The 21-year-old, who only made his senior debut for Argentina in September 2022, played in all of his country’s seven games at the tournament.\n\nThe midfielder saw off stern competition from the likes of team-mate Julian Alvarez, England’s Jude Bellingham, Portugal’s Goncalo Ramos, and France’s Aurelien Tchouameni to claim the award.\n\n#### **What they said**\n\n"I know Enzo very well, here from the national team and I also played against him in the Champions League. He deserves it, because he’s a spectacular kid and a very important player for us." – Lionel Messi on Enzo Fernandez.\n\n### **Golden Glove Award: Emiliano Martinez**\n\n**Age**: 30**Position**: Goalkeeper**Club**: Aston Villa**Nation**: Argentina\n\nAfter helping Argentina to a Copa America triumph last year, Emiliano Martinez went one further by adding a global title to his list of international trophies. The stopper kept three clean sheets at Qatar 2022, as well as coming out victorious in two shoot-outs.\n\nMartinez played every minute of Argentina’s campaign and saved Kingsley Coman\'s spot-kick in the final shoot-out.\n\n#### **What they said**\n\n"The World Cup is something I have been dreaming of. I have no words to express what I\'m feeling." – Emiliano Martinez.\n\n### **Golden Boot Award: Kylian Mbappe**\n\n**Age**: 23**Position**: Forward**Club**: Paris Saint-Germain**Nation**: France\n\nKylian Mbappe took home the Golden Boot Award after finishing top scorer with eight goals. Mbappe made history by becoming just the second man to net a World Cup final hat-trick, after England’s Geoff Hurst in 1966. With four goals across 2018 and 2022, the talisman has also established himself as the highest-scoring player in World Cup final history.\n\nMbappe is a two-time FIFA FIFPRO Men’s World 11 winner, having been named in the 2018 and 2019 teams.\n\n### **Golden Ball Award: Lionel Messi**\n\n**Age**: 35**Position**: Forward**Club**: Paris Saint-Germain**Nation**: Argentina\n\nLionel Messi made history by becoming the first man to win the World Cup Golden Ball twice. After first claiming the award for the World Cup’s best player at Brazil 2014, Messi picked up the Qatar 2022 gong after providing seven goals and three assists – and helping Argentina win the trophy for the first time in 32 years. Mbappe and Luka Modric received the Silver Ball and Bronze Ball respectively.\n\nMessi, who has been named in 15 successive FIFA FIFPRO Men’s World 11s, netted his 97th and 98th goals for Argentina in the final.\n\n#### **What they said**\n\n"Messi should have a place in the next World Cup. If he wants to continue playing, the \'10\' will always be his." – Argentina manager Lionel Scaloni.\n\n[News\n\n### Five-star Guardado, Messi and Ronaldo make men\'s World Cup history](/en/supporting-players/player-influence/player-impact/five-star-guardado-messi-and-ronaldo-make-men-s-world-cup-history)\n\n[### FIFPRO launches series for professional footballers to talk about social topics](/en/supporting-players/player-influence/shine-a-light/fifpro-launches-series-for-professional-footballers-to-talk-about-social-topics)\n\n[Statement\n\n### FIFPRO Statement: International Match Calendar](/en/supporting-players/competitions-innovation-and-growth/competition-design-and-structures/fifpro-statement-international-match-calendar-men-and-women)\n\n ', 'images': []}, {'url': 'https://www.olympics.com/en/news/fifa-world-cup-2022-complete-list-award-winners', 'raw_content': "# FIFA World Cup 2022: Golden Ball, Golden Boot, Golden Glove - complete list of all award winners\n\nLionel Messi, Kylian Mbappe and Emi Martinez scooped the big prizes at the FIFA World Cup 2022 in Qatar.\n\nPicture by 2022 Getty Images\n\nBy Olympics.com\n\n18 December 2022 21:59 GMT+03 min read\n\n[**Lionel Messi**](https://olympics.com/en/athletes/lionel-messi), **Kylian Mbappe** and **Emiliano Martinez** collected the big individual prizes at [**FIFA World Cup 2022**](https://olympics.com/en/sport-events/2022-fifa-football-world-cup-qatar/) in Qatar.\n\nJust a matter of minutes before lifting the World Cup trophy for the first time, following [Argentina's epic penalty shoot-out win over France](https://olympics.com/en/news/lionel-messi-world-cup-final-trophy-argentina-france-2022-penalties), Messi received the Golden Ball awarded to the tournament's best player.\n\nOn the stage, he gave the World Cup trophy a kiss as he held his personal gong.\n\n[Start 2026 in Italy! The Olympic Winter Games are just a TICKET away! 🏂❄️🎿Sign-up for reminders of ticket releases and all the latest news of your favourite national Olympic teams and athletes trying to qualify! 🎫](https://www.olympics.com/en/sign-in?entry_point_type=instory_campaign&entry_point_tag=mico-2026&template=mico-2026-gtwa&origin=https%3A%2F%2Ftickets.milanocortina2026.org%2Fen%2F%3Futm_medium%3Dioc_website%26utm_source%3Dolympics.com%26utm_campaign%3Dmico_gtweb+)\n\nPicture by 2022 Getty Images\n\nMessi had won the Golden Ball in 2014 in Brazil where Argentina **suffered heartbreak in the final**, going down 1-0 in extra time to Germany.\n\nBut this time, the 35-year-old got his hands on the one trophy that had thus far eluded him throughout his spectacular career.\n\nMbappe took the Silver Ball for second place with 2018 Golden Ball winner **Luka Modric** receiving the Bronze Ball for third.\n\nREAD MORE: [Lionel Messi secures Golden Ball for second time](https://olympics.com/en/news/fifa-world-cup-2022-top-players-the-race-for-the-golden-ball)\n\nLionel Messi FIFA World 2022 stats\n\n| Lionel Messi | Goals | Assists | Shots | Shot on Target | Passes | Crosses | Tackles | Fouls Committed | Fouls Won |\n| vs Croatia (90 minutes) | 1 | 1 | 2 | 2 | 40 | 2 | 0 | 1 | 1 |\n| vs Netherlands (extra-time and penalties) | 1 | 1 | 6 | 2 | 45 | 2 | 0 | 3 | 8 |\n| vs Australia (90 minutes) | 1 | 0 | 6 | 2 | 58 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 2 |\n| vs Poland (90 minutes) | 0 | 0 | 7 | 4 | 70 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 2 |\n| vs Mexico (90 minutes) | 1 | 1 | 2 | 1 | 41 | 3 | 1 | 3 | 5 |\n| vs Saudi Arabia (90 minutes) | 1 | 0 | 4 | 3 | 40 | 5 | 0 | 1 | 2 |\n| Total | 5 | 3 | 27 | 14 | 294 | 14 | 3 | 8 | 20 |\n\n## Kylian Mbappe pips Lionel Messi to Golden Boot\n\nMbappe took the Golden Boot after his hat-trick in the final put him on eight goals, one clear of PSG club colleague Messi who scored twice on the day.\n\nThat took Mbappe to 12 goals in just two tournaments with **Miroslav Klose's** record of 16 World Cup goals definitely in his sights.\n\nThe 23-year-old has scored 36 goals in 66 France appearances and continues to bolster his reputation as one of the finest forwards on the planet.\n\nREAD MORE: [Kylian Mbappe wins race for Golden Boot](https://olympics.com/en/news/golden-boot-top-goalscorer-fifa-world-cup-2022-qatar)\n\nPicture by Richard Heathcote/Getty Images\n\n## Emi Martinez takes Golden Glove after more penalty heroics\n\nArgentina goalkeeper Martinez scooped the Golden Glove for best goalkeeper after saving a penalty from **Kingsley Coman** in the shoot-out.\n\nHe also made a wonderful save late in extra time to deny **Randal Kolo Muani** a goal which would have put France ahead for the first time.\n\nThe Aston Villa shotstopper had been the hero of Argentina's quarter-final victory over the Netherlands, making two saves in the penalty shoot-out.\n\nREAD MORE: [Emiliano Martinez receives Golden Glove award](https://olympics.com/en/news/fifa-world-cup-2022-the-race-for-the-golden-glove)\n\nPicture by 2022 Getty Images\n\n## Enzo Fernandez claims Young Player award\n\nThere was another Argentinian winner in Qatar as **Enzo Fernandez** claimed the Young Player of the Tournament award.\n\nThe Benfica midfielder was a substitute in his country's first two matches, but his **spectacular strike against Mexico** helped cement him a starting berth.\n\nFernandez, who turns 22 next month, formed a strong midfield trio alongside **Rodrigo De Paul** and **Alexis Mac Allister** which allowed Messi to weave his magic.\n\nHis performances have attracted the attentions of the biggest clubs in Europe with Real Madrid and Liverpool reportedly interested in acquiring his services.\n\nBeaten quarter-finalists **England** received the Fair Play Award after picking up just one booking in five matches.\n\nPicture by 2022 Getty Images\n\n[20 November - 18 December 2022Football | World Cup 2022 | Qatar\xa0 | Qatar](https://www.olympics.com/en/sport-events/2022-fifa-football-world-cup-qatar/)", 'images': []}, {'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_final',
