Women\'s Coach\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2022&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: The Best FIFA Women\'s Coach")]\n\nSee also: [The Best FIFA Football Coach](/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Coach "The Best FIFA Football Coach")\n\nSix coaches were initially shortlisted on 12 January 2023.[[25]](#cite_note-25) The three finalists were revealed on 9 February 2023.[[26]](#cite_note-26)\n\n[Sarina Wiegman](/wiki/Sarina_Wiegman "Sarina Wiegman") won the award with 28 scoring points.[[27]](#cite_note-27)[[6]](#cite_note-voting_results-6)[[7]](#cite_note-result_breakdown-7)[[28]](#cite_note-28)\n\n| Rank | Coach | Team(s) managed | Points |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| The finalists | | | | |\n| 1 | [Sarina Wiegman](/wiki/Sarina_Wiegman "Sarina Wiegman") | [England](/wiki/England_women%27s_national_football_team "England women\'s national football team") | 28 |\n| 2 | [Sonia Bompastor](/wiki/Sonia_Bompastor "Sonia Bompastor") | [Lyon](/wiki/Olympique_Lyonnais_F%C3%A9minin "Olympique Lyonnais Féminin") | 18 |\n| 3 | [Pia Sundhage](/wiki/Pia_Sundhage "Pia Sundhage") | [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_women%27s_national_football_team "Brazil women\'s national football team") | 10 |\n| Other candidates | | | | |\n| 4 | [Emma Hayes](/wiki/Emma_Hayes "Emma Hayes") | [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C._Women "Chelsea F.C. Women") | 10 |\n| 5 | [Martina Voss-Tecklenburg](/wiki/Martina_Voss-Tecklenburg "Martina Voss-Tecklenburg") | [Germany](/wiki/Germany_women%27s_national_football_team "Germany women\'s national football team") | 6 |\n| 6 | [Bev Priestman](/wiki/Bev_Priestman "Bev Priestman") | [Canada](/wiki/Canada_women%27s_national_soccer_team "Canada women\'s national soccer team") | 0 |\n\n### FIFA Puskás Award\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2022&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: FIFA Puskás Award")]\n\nSee also: [FIFA Puskás Award](/wiki/FIFA_Pusk%C3%A1s_Award "FIFA Puskás Award")\n\nThe eleven players initially shortlisted for the award were announced on 12 January 2023.[[29]](#cite_note-29) The three finalists were revealed on 10 February 2023.[[30]](#cite_note-30) All goals up for consideration were scored from 8 August 2021 to 18 December 2022. Every registered FIFA.com user was allowed to participate in the final vote until 3 February 2023, with the questionnaire being presented on the official website of FIFA. The selected goals were also voted on by a panel of "FIFA experts". Both groups\' votes weighed equally on the ultimate winner of the award.[[31]](#cite_note-31)\n\n[Marcin Oleksy](/wiki/Marcin_Oleksy "Marcin Oleksy") won the award with 21 scoring points, becoming the first [amputee footballer](/wiki/Amputee_football "Amputee football") to earn the honour.[[32]](#cite_note-32)[[7]](#cite_note-result_breakdown-7)\n\n| Rank | Player | Match | Competition | Date | Points |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| The finalists | | | | | |\n| 1 | [Marcin Oleksy](/wiki/Marcin_Oleksy "Marcin Oleksy") | **[Warta Poznań](/wiki/Warta_Pozna%C5%84 "Warta Poznań")** – [Stal Rzeszów](/wiki/Stal_Rzesz%C3%B3w_(football) "Stal Rzeszów (football)") | 2022 PZU Amp Futbol Ekstraklasa | 6 November 2022 | 21 |\n| 2 | [Dimitri Payet](/wiki/Dimitri_Payet "Dimitri Payet") | **[Marseille](/wiki/Olympique_de_Marseille "Olympique de Marseille")** – [PAOK](/wiki/PAOK_FC "PAOK FC") | [2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_UEFA_Europa_Conference_League "2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League") | 7 April 2022 | 20 |\n| 3 | [Richarlison](/wiki/Richarlison "Richarlison") | **[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team")** – [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia_national_football_team "Serbia national football team") | [2022 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") | 24 November 2022 | 17 |\n| Other candidates | | | | | |\n| Unranked | [Mario Balotelli](/wiki/Mario_Balotelli "Mario Balotelli") | **[Adana Demirspor](/wiki/Adana_Demirspor "Adana Demirspor")** – [Göztepe](/wiki/G%C3%B6ztepe_S.K. "Göztepe S.K.") | [2021–22 Süper Lig](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_S%C3%BCper_Lig "2021–22 Süper Lig") | 22 May 2022 | N/A |\n| [Francisco González Metilli](/wiki/Francisco_Gonz%C3%A1lez_Metilli "Francisco González Metilli") | [Rosario Central](/wiki/Rosario_Central "Rosario Central") – **[Central Córdoba](/wiki/Central_C%C3%B3rdoba_de_Santiago_del_Estero "Central Córdoba de Santiago del Estero")** | [2022 Argentine Primera División](/wiki/2022_Argentine_Primera_Divisi%C3%B3n "2022 Argentine Primera División") | 1 August 2022 |\n| [Amandine Henry](/wiki/Amandine_Henry "Amandine Henry") | [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona_Femen%C3%AD "FC Barcelona Femení") – **[Lyon](/wiki/Olympique_Lyonnais_F%C3%A9minin "Olympique Lyonnais Féminin")** | [2021–22 UEFA Women\'s Champions League](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_UEFA_Women%27s_Champions_League "2021–22 UEFA Women\'s Champions League") | 21 May 2022 |\n| [Théo Hernandez](/wiki/Th%C3%A9o_Hernandez "Théo Hernandez") | **[Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C. Milan")** – [Atalanta](/wiki/Atalanta_B.C. "Atalanta B.C.") | [2021–22 Serie A](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Serie_A "2021–22 Serie A") | 15 May 2022 |\n| [Alou Kuol](/wiki/Alou_Kuol "Alou Kuol") | [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq_national_under-23_football_team "Iraq national under-23 football team") – **[Australia](/wiki/Australia_men%27s_national_under-23_soccer_team "Australia men\'s national under-23 soccer team")** | [2022 AFC U-23 Asian Cup](/wiki/2022_AFC_U-23_Asian_Cup "2022 AFC U-23 Asian Cup") | 4 June 2022 |\n| [Kylian Mbappé](/wiki/Kylian_Mbapp%C3%A9 "Kylian Mbappé") | [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team") – **[France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football team")** | [2022 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") | 18 December 2022 |\n| [Salma Paralluelo](/wiki/Salma_Paralluelo "Salma Paralluelo") | [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona_Femen%C3%AD "FC Barcelona Femení") – **[Villarreal](/wiki/Villarreal_CF_(women) "Villarreal CF (women)")** | [2021–22 Primera División (women)](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Primera_Divisi%C3%B3n_(women) "2021–22 Primera División (women)") | 2 April 2022 |\n| [Alessia Russo](/wiki/Alessia_Russo "Alessia Russo") | **[England](/wiki/England_women%27s_national_football_team "England women\'s national football team")** – [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_women%27s_national_football_team "Sweden women\'s national football team") | [UEFA Women\'s Euro 2022](/wiki/UEFA_Women%27s_Euro_2022 "UEFA Women\'s Euro 2022") | 26 July 2022 |\n\n### FIFA Fan Award\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2022&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: FIFA Fan Award")]\n\nSee also: [FIFA Fan Award](/wiki/FIFA_Fan_Award "FIFA Fan Award")\n\nThe award celebrates the best fan moments or gestures of August 2021 to December 2022, regardless of championship, gender or nationality. The shortlist was compiled by a panel of FIFA experts.[[33]](#cite_note-33)\n\n[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team") fans won the award with over 650,000 registered votes.[[34]](#cite_note-34)[[7]](#cite_note-result_breakdown-7)\n\n| Rank | Fan(s) | Reason | Votes | % of total votes |\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\n| Nominees | | | | |\n| 1 | [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team") fans | Their support in travelling to Qatar to support their teams eventual winning run at the [2022 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup"), and followed by the millions of fans welcoming the team home to [Buenos Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires "Buenos Aires") following their tournament win. | 656,253 | 41.88% |\n| 2 | [Japan](/wiki/Japan_national_football_team "Japan national football team") fans | Traditional nature of staying behind following their nation’s games at the [2022 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") to clean up the stadium. | 526,887 | 33.63% |\n| 3 | Abdullah Al Salmi | Hiking 1,600 km across the Arabian desert from [Jeddah](/wiki/Jeddah "Jeddah") to Qatar to support his home nation at the [2022 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup"). | 383,643 | 24.49% |\n\n### FIFA Fair Play Award\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2022&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: FIFA Fair Play Award")]\n\nSee also: [FIFA Fair Play Award](/wiki/FIFA_Fair_Play_Award "FIFA Fair Play Award")\n\n| Winner | Team | Reason |\n| --- | --- | --- |\n| [Luka Lochoshvili](/wiki/Luka_Lochoshvili "Luka Lochoshvili") | [Wolfsberger AC](/wiki/Wolfsberger_AC "Wolfsberger AC") | Saved [Georg Teigl](/wiki/Georg_Teigl "Georg Teigl")\'s life, clearing the defender’s airways after he swallowed his tongue. Thanks to Lochoshvili\'s actions, Teigl regained consciousness and then was treated at a local hospital.[[35]](#cite_note-:0-35) |\n\n### The Best FIFA Special Award\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2022&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: The Best FIFA Special Award")]\n\nAn additional award was given out posthumously in tribute to the late [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9 "Pelé"), to recognize his role and contribution to the sport of football. The award was received by Pelé\'s wife Marcia Aoki.[[36]](#cite_note-36)\n\n| Winner | Reason |\n| --- | --- |\n| [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9 "Pelé") | Posthumously awarded as a tribute and special recognition for his role in football. |\n\n### FIFA FIFPRO Men\'s World 11\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2022&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: FIFA FIFPRO Men\'s World 11")]\n\nSee also: [FIFA FIFPRO World 11](/wiki/FIFA_FIFPRO_World_11 "FIFA FIFPRO World 11")\n\nThe 26–player men\'s shortlist was announced on 13 February 2023.[[37]](#cite_note-37)\n\nThe players chosen were [Thibaut Courtois](/wiki/Thibaut_Courtois "Thibaut Courtois") as goalkeeper, [Achraf Hakimi](/wiki/Achraf_Hakimi "Achraf Hakimi"), [Virgil van Dijk](/wiki/Virgil_van_Dijk "Virgil van Dijk") and [João Cancelo](/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Cancelo "João Cancelo") as defenders, [Kevin De Bruyne](/wiki/Kevin_De_Bruyne "Kevin De Bruyne"), [Casemiro](/wiki/Casemiro "Casemiro") and [Luka Modrić](/wiki/Luka_Modri%C4%87 "Luka Modrić") as midfielders, and [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi"), [Karim Benzema](/wiki/Karim_Benzema "Karim Benzema"), [Erling Haaland](/wiki/Erling_Haaland "Erling Haaland") and [Kylian Mbappé](/wiki/Kylian_Mbapp%C3%A9 "Kylian Mbappé") as forwards.[[38]](#cite_note-38)[[39]](#cite_note-39)\n\n**[Courtois](/wiki/Thibaut_Courtois "Thibaut Courtois")**\n\n**[Van Dijk](/wiki/Virgil_van_Dijk "Virgil van Dijk")**\n\n**[Hakimi](/wiki/Achraf_Hakimi "Achraf Hakimi")**\n\n**[Cancelo](/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Cancelo "João Cancelo")**\n\n**[De Bruyne](/wiki/Kevin_De_Bruyne "Kevin De "Manchester United F.C.") * [Al Nassr](/wiki/Al_Nassr_FC "Al Nassr FC") |\n\n### FIFA FIFPRO Women\'s World 11\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2022&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: FIFA FIFPRO Women\'s World 11")]\n\nSee also: [FIFA FIFPRO World 11](/wiki/FIFA_FIFPRO_World_11 "FIFA FIFPRO World 11")\n\nThe 23–player women\'s shortlist was announced on 13 February 2023.[[40]](#cite_note-40)\n\nThe players chosen were [Christiane Endler](/wiki/Christiane_Endler "Christiane Endler") as goalkeeper, [Lucy Bronze](/wiki/Lucy_Bronze "Lucy Bronze"), [Mapi León](/wiki/Mapi_Le%C3%B3n "Mapi León"), [Wendie Renard](/wiki/Wendie_Renard "Wendie Renard") and [Leah Williamson](/wiki/Leah_Williamson "Leah Williamson") as defenders, [Lena Oberdorf](/wiki/Lena_Oberdorf "Lena Oberdorf"), [Alexia Putellas](/wiki/Alexia_Putellas "Alexia Putellas") and [Keira Walsh](/wiki/Keira_Walsh "Keira Walsh") as midfielders, and [Sam Kerr](/wiki/Sam_Kerr "Sam Kerr"), [Beth Mead](/wiki/Beth_Mead "Beth Mead") and [Alex Morgan](/wiki/Alex_Morgan "Alex Morgan") as forwards.[[41]](#cite_note-41)[[42]](#cite_note-42)\n\n**[Endler](/wiki/Christiane_Endler "Christiane Endler")**\n\n**[León](/wiki/Mapi_Le%C3%B3n "Mapi León")**\n\n**[Williamson](/wiki/Leah_Williamson [latest accepted revision](/wiki/Wikipedia:Pending_changes "Wikipedia:Pending changes"), [reviewed](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Log&type=review&page=FIFA_World_Cup_awards) on *24 August 2025*.\n\nMen\'s football awards\n\nThis article is about the men\'s senior tournament. For the women\'s tournament, see [FIFA Women\'s World Cup awards](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_awards "FIFA Women\'s World Cup awards").\n\nAt the end of each [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup") final tournament, several awards are presented to the players and teams who have distinguished themselves in various aspects of the game.\n\n## Awards\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Awards")]\n\n* There are currently five post-tournament awards from the FIFA Technical Study Group:[[1]](#cite_note-FIFA-2010-1)[[2]](#cite_note-Fifa-Tech-2018-2)\n  + the **Golden Ball** (currently commercially termed "[adidas](/wiki/Adidas "Adidas") Golden Ball") for best player, first awarded in [1982](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World Cup").\n  + the **Golden Boot** (currently commercially termed "adidas Golden Boot", formerly known as the "adidas Golden Shoe" from 1982 to 2006) for top goalscorer, first awarded in 1982;\n  + the **Golden Glove** (currently commercially termed "adidas Golden Glove", formerly known as the "[Lev Yashin](/wiki/Lev_Yashin "Lev Yashin") Award" from 1994 to 2006) for best goalkeeper, first awarded in [1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup");\n  + the **FIFA Young Player Award** (formerly known as the "Best Young Player Award" from 2006 to 2010) for best player under 21 years of age at the start of the calendar year, first awarded in [2006](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup");\n  + the **FIFA Fair Play Trophy** for the team that advanced to the second round with the best record of fair play, first awarded in [1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World Cup").\n* There is currently one award voted on by fans during the tournament:\n  + the **Player of the Match**  (currently commercially termed "[Budweiser](/wiki/Budweiser "Budweiser") Player of the Match", formerly known as the "Man of the Match" from 2002 to 2018) for outstanding performance during each match of the tournament, first awarded in [2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup").\n* There are currently two awards voted on by fans after the conclusion of the tournament:\n  + the **Goal of the Tournament**, (currently commercially termed "[Hyundai](/wiki/Hyundai_Motor_Company "Hyundai Motor Company") Goal of the Tournament") for the fans\' best goal scored during the tournament, first awarded in [2006](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup");\n  + the **Most Entertaining Team** for the team that has entertained the public the most, during the World Cup final tournament, as determined by a poll of the general public.\n* One other award was given between 1994 and 2006:[[3]](#cite_note-USA_Today-2010-3)\n  + an **All-Star Team** comprising the best players of the tournament chosen by the FIFA Technical Study Group. From 2010 onwards, all Dream Teams or Statistical Teams are unofficial, as reported by FIFA itself.\n\n## Golden Ball\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Golden Ball")]\n\n"FIFA World Cup Golden Ball" redirects here. For the women\'s award, see [FIFA Women\'s World Cup Golden Ball](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_Golden_Ball "FIFA Women\'s World Cup Golden Ball").\n\nThe **Golden Ball** award is presented to the best player at each FIFA World Cup finals, with a shortlist drawn up by the FIFA technical committee (Technical Study Group) and the winner voted for by representatives of the media.[[4]](#cite_note-footballcoal-2022-4) Those who finish as runners-up in the vote receive the *Silver Ball* and *Bronze Ball* awards as the second and third most outstanding players in the tournament respectively. The current award was introduced in the 1982 FIFA World Cup, sponsored by [Adidas](/wiki/Adidas "Adidas") and *[France Football](/wiki/France_Football "France Football")*.[[5]](#cite_note-82debut-5) [Oliver Kahn](/wiki/Oliver_Kahn "Oliver Kahn") is to date the only goalkeeper to have won the award, which he did in the 2002 FIFA World Cup. At the 2022 FIFA World Cup, [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi") became the first player to win a second Golden Ball.[[6]](#cite_note-FIFA.com-2022-6)\n\n### Official winners (1982–present)\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Official winners (1982–present)")]\n\nGolden Ball[[7]](#cite_note-FIFA_Awards-7)\n\n| World Cup [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football team") | 0 | 0 | 1 | **1** |\n\n### Unofficial winner (1978 Argentina)\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Unofficial winner (1978 Argentina)")]\n\nA group of journalists and experts selected the best player of the [1978 tournament](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World Cup"),[[8]](#cite_note-Mundo_Deportivo-1978-8) and their selection is recognised by the [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA") website. FIFA recognises only this selection besides the Golden Ball award. [Hans Krankl](/wiki/Hans_Krankl "Hans Krankl") received the same number of votes as [Dirceu](/wiki/Dirceu "Dirceu") at the time,[[8]](#cite_note-Mundo_Deportivo-1978-8) and was not chosen as the third best player by FIFA later.\n\nBest player[[8]](#cite_note-Mundo_Deportivo-1978-8)\n\n| Winner | Runner-up | Third place |\n| [Mario Kempes](/wiki/Mario_Kempes "Mario Kempes")[[9]](#cite_note-FIFA-2018-9) | [Paolo Rossi](/wiki/Paolo_Rossi "Paolo Rossi")[[10]](#cite_note-78WC-10) | [Dirceu](/wiki/Dirceu "Dirceu")[[10]](#cite_note-78WC-10) |\n\n### Media\'s selections (1930–1974)\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Media\'s selections (1930–1974)")]\n\nAuthoritative football [historian](/wiki/Historian "Historian") and [statistician](/wiki/Statistician "Statistician") [Ejikeme Ikwunze](/wiki/Ejikeme_Ikwunze "Ejikeme Ikwunze"), popularly called "Mr. Football", published a list of the best players in his book *World Cup (1930-2010): A Statistical Summary*,[[11]](#cite_note-Ikwunze-11) and it gained the most attention among experts\' selections about the best players until 1978. This work is part of the official FIFA library.[[12]](#cite_note-swisscovery-1930-12) A considerable number of other media agreed with him.[[13]](#cite_note-SI-2018-13)[[14]](#cite_note-Holt-2014-14)[[15]](#cite_note-Topend_Sports-2021-15)[[16]](#cite_note-BBC_Sport-2021-16)\n\nOn 2 August 1950, Dr. [Friedebert Becker](/w/index.php?title=Friedebert_Becker&action=edit&redlink=1 "Friedebert Becker (page does not exist)")\xa0[[de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedebert_Becker "de:Friedebert Becker")], the editor-in-chief of [*Kicker*](/wiki/Kicker_(sports_magazine) "Kicker (sports magazine)") (then *Sport-Magazin*), chose his best players of the tournament.[[17]](#cite_note-Sport_Magazin-1950-17)\n\n*[France Football](/wiki/France_Football "France Football")*, the sponsor of Golden Ball and [Ballon d\'Or](/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or "Ballon d\'Or"), selected the best player of the 1966 FIFA World Cup at that time with *[L\'Équipe](/wiki/L%27%C3%89quipe "L\'Équipe")*, and [Bobby Charlton](/wiki/Bobby_Charlton "Bobby Charlton") became the winner.[[18]](#cite_note-FranceFootball-18)\n\nIn 1998, the Argentinian newspaper *[Clarín](/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper) "Clarín (Argentine newspaper)")* provided a brief description of each star player dating back to 1930. Some are controversial decisions as is the case with retrospective awards. The 1998 winner was awarded after the tournament ended.[[19]](#cite_note-Clarin-2018-19)\n\nBest players by medium\n\n| World Cup | Medium | First place | Second place | Third place |\n| [1930 [Ronnie Hellström](/wiki/Ronnie_Hellstr%C3%B6m "Ronnie Hellström") |\n| [Castrol Football](/wiki/Castrol_performance_index "Castrol performance index")[[25]](#cite_note-The_Guardian-2002-25) | [Johan Cruyff](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff "Johan Cruyff") | [Grzegorz Lato](/wiki/Grzegorz_Lato "Grzegorz Lato") | [Kazimierz Deyna](/wiki/Kazimierz_Deyna "Kazimierz Deyna") |\n| *[Clarín](/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper) "Clarín (Argentine newspaper)")* | [Johan Cruyff](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff "Johan Cruyff") | — | — |\n\n## Golden Boot\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Golden Boot")]\n\n"FIFA World Cup Golden Boot" redirects here. For the women\'s award, see [FIFA Women\'s World Cup Golden Boot](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_Golden_Boot "FIFA Women\'s World Cup Golden Boot").\n\nThe **Golden Boot** or **Golden Shoe** award goes to the top goalscorer of the FIFA World Cup. While every World Cup had a ranking of the goalscorers, the first time an award was given was in 1982,[[7]](#cite_note-FIFA_Awards-7) under the name Golden Shoe.[[5]](#cite_note-82debut-5) It was rechristened Golden Boot in 2010.[[43]](#cite_note-glance-43) FIFA sometimes lists the top goalscorers of previous Cups among the Golden Boot winners.[[44]](#cite_note-boot-44)\n\nIf there is more than one player with the same number of goals, since 1994 the tie-breaker goes to the player with more assists. If there is still more than one player, the tie (since 2006) is decided by minutes played in the tournament, with the player playing fewest minutes ranked first. A Silver Boot and a Bronze Boot are also awarded for the second and third-highest goalscorers respectively.\n\n| Top goalscorer[[45]](#cite_note-45)[[46]](#cite_note-46) |\n| --- |\n| World Cup | Top goalscorer | Goals | Runners-up | Goals | Third place | Goals |\n| [1930 Uruguay](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup "1930 FIFA World Cup") | [Guillermo Stábile](/wiki/Guillermo_St%C3%A1bile "Guillermo Griezmann](/wiki/Antoine_Griezmann "Antoine Griezmann") | 4[[l]](#cite_note-Griezmann,_Lukaku,_[[Denis_Cheryshev]],_[[Cristiano_Ronaldo]]_and_[[Kylian_Mbappé]]-73) | [Romelu Lukaku](/wiki/Romelu_Lukaku "Romelu Lukaku") | 4[[l]](#cite_note-Griezmann,_Lukaku,_[[Denis_Cheryshev]],_[[Cristiano_Ronaldo]]_and_[[Kylian_Mbappé]]-73) |\n| [2022 Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") | [Kylian Mbappé](/wiki/Kylian_Mbapp%C3%A9 "Kylian Mbappé") | 8 | [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi") | 7 | [Olivier Giroud](/wiki/Olivier_Giroud "Olivier Giroud") | 4[[m]](#cite_note-Giroud_and_Julián_Álvarez-75) |\n| Notes |\n| 1. **[^](#cite_ref-48)** FIFA initially credited Nejedlý with only four goals, which would make him joint top scorer with [Angelo Schiavio](/wiki/Angelo_Schiavio "Angelo Schiavio") of [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team") and [Edmund Conen](/wiki/Edmund_Conen "Edmund Conen") of [Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football team"). However, FIFA changed it to five goals in November 2006, making Nejedlý the outright top scorer.[[47]](#cite_note-hattrick-47) 2. **[^](#cite_ref-49)** FIFA initially credited Leônidas with eight goals. However, in November 2006, FIFA confirmed that in the quarter-final tie against Czechoslovakia, he had scored once, not twice as FIFA had originally recorded, meaning he had scored only seven goals in total.[[47]](#cite_note-hattrick-47) 3. **[^](#cite_ref-52)** There was controversy regarding the number of goals Brazilian Ademir had scored in 1950, as a result of incomplete data concerning the Final Round game Brazil vs. Spain (6–1). The 5–0 goal had been credited to Jair, but is now credited to Ademir.[[48]](#cite_note-50)[[49]](#cite_note-51) 4. **[^](#cite_ref-55)** Salenko is the only player to win the award playing for a team that were eliminated in the group stage. His six goals are the only international goals he ever scored. 5. **[^](#cite_ref-57)** Despite the assist tiebreaker, Salenko and Stoichkov remained tied with six goals and one assist each, and both received the Golden Shoe.[[52]](#cite_note-busw1994-56) 6. **[^](#cite_ref-59)** Romário and Andersson surpassed the other two players with five goals ([Jürgen Klinsmann](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Klinsmann "Jürgen Klinsmann") and [Roberto Baggio](/wiki/Roberto_Baggio "Roberto Baggio")) by having three assists each.[[52]](#cite_note-busw1994-56)[[53]](#cite_note-58) 7. **[^](#cite_ref-61)** Both runners-up had the same number of assists, and each received the Silver Shoe. 8. **[^](#cite_ref-64)** During the tournament, after the group stage match against Costa Rica, Ronaldo logged a protest against the crediting of a goal as an own goal, and FIFA granted him the change.[[56]](#cite_note-63) 9. ^ [***a***](#cite_ref-Crespo_and_Ronaldo_67-0) [***b***](#cite_ref-Crespo_and_Ronaldo_67-1) Eight players had scored three goals. Ronaldo, Crespo and [Zinedine Zidane](/wiki/Zinedine_Zidane "Zinedine Zidane") stood out for having one assist, and then the two recipients were determined by less playtime (308 minutes for Crespo, 411 for Ronaldo, 559 for Zidane).[[58]](#cite_note-66) 10. ^ [***a***](#cite_ref-Müller,_Villa,_Sneijder_and_Forlán_69-0) [***b***](#cite_ref-Müller,_Villa,_Sneijder_and_Forlán_69-1) [***c***](#cite_ref-Müller,_Villa,_Sneijder_and_Forlán_69-2) Müller, Villa, Sneijder and [Diego Forlán](/wiki/Diego_Forl%C3%A1n "Diego Forlán") tied with five goals. Müller won by virtue of having more assists (three) than the rest (each had one). Villa won the Silver Boot due to playing fewer minutes than Sneijder, and Sneijder won the Bronze Boot due to having played fewer minutes than Forlán.[[59]](#cite_note-68) 11. **[^](#cite_ref-71)** Neymar, [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi") and [Robin van Persie](/wiki/Robin_van_Persie "Robin van Persie") all had four goals in the tournament. Neymar received the Bronze Boot for playing fewer minutes than his competitors (480; Messi played 693 minutes, and Van Persie, 548).[[60]](#cite_note-70) 12. ^ [***a***](#cite_ref-Griezmann,_Lukaku,_[[Denis_Cheryshev]],_[[Cristiano_Ronaldo]]_and_[[Kylian_Mbappé]]_73-0) [***b***](#cite_ref-Griezmann,_Lukaku,_[[Denis_Cheryshev]],_[[Cristiano_Ronaldo]]_and_[[Kylian_Mbappé]]_73-1) Griezmann, Lukaku, [Denis Cheryshev](/wiki/Denis_Cheryshev "Denis Cheryshev"), [Cristiano Ronaldo](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo "Cristiano Ronaldo") and [Kylian Mbappé](/wiki/Kylian_Mbapp%C3%A9 "Kylian Mbappé") tied with four goals. In the assists tiebreaker, Griezmann won the Silver Boot by virtue of having two, while Lukaku got the Bronze Boot as he had one. The rest had zero.[[61]](#cite_note-72) 13. **[^](#cite_ref-Giroud_and_Julián_Álvarez_75-0)** Giroud and [Julián Álvarez](/wiki/Juli%C3%A1n_%C3%81lvarez_(footballer) "Julián Álvarez (footballer)") tied with four goals. Giroud won the Bronze Boot due to playing fewer minutes than Álvarez.[[62]](#cite_note-74) |\n\n## Golden Glove\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Golden Glove")]\n\n"FIFA World Cup Golden Glove" redirects here. For the women\'s award, see [FIFA Women\'s World Cup Golden Glove](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_Golden_Glove "FIFA Women\'s World Cup Golden Glove").\n\nThe **Golden Glove** award is awarded to the best goalkeeper of the tournament. The award was introduced with the name "[Lev Yashin](/wiki/Lev_Yashin "Lev Yashin") Award" in 1994, in honor of the late [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") goalkeeper.[[7]](#cite_note-FIFA_Awards-7) It was rechristened "Golden Glove" in 2010. The FIFA Technical Study Group recognises the top goalkeeper of the tournament based on the player\'s performance throughout the final competition. Although goalkeepers have this specific award for their position, they are still eligible for the Golden Ball as well, as when Oliver Kahn was awarded in 2002.[[63]](#cite_note-76)\n\nOfficial Award\n\n| Lev Yashin Award |\n| World Cup | Lev Yashin Award | Clean sheets |\n| [1994 United States](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup") | [Michel Preud\'homme](/wiki/Michel_Preud%27homme "Michel Preud\'homme") | 2 |\n| [1998 France](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup") | [Fabien Barthez](/wiki/Fabien_Barthez "Fabien Barthez") | 5 |\n| [2002 South Korea/Japan](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") | [Oliver Kahn](/wiki/Oliver_Kahn "Oliver Kahn") | 5 |\n| [2006 Germany](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") | [Gianluigi Buffon](/wiki/Gianluigi_Buffon "Gianluigi Buffon") | 5 |\n| Golden Glove |\n| World Cup | Golden Glove | Clean sheets |\n| [2010 South Africa](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup") | [Iker Casillas](/wiki/Iker_Casillas "Iker Casillas") | 5 |\n| [2014 Brazil](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup") | [Manuel Neuer](/wiki/Manuel_Neuer "Manuel Neuer") | 4 |\n| [2018 Russia](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") | [Thibaut Courtois](/wiki/Thibaut_Courtois "Thibaut Courtois") | 3 |\n| [2022 Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") | [Emiliano Martínez](/wiki/Emiliano_Mart%C3%ADnez "Emiliano Martínez") | 3 |\n\n## FIFA Young Player Award\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: FIFA Young Player Award")]\n\n"FIFA World Cup Young Player Award" redirects here. For the women\'s award, see [FIFA Women\'s World Cup Young Player Award](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_Young_Player_Award "FIFA Women\'s World Cup Young Player Award").\n\nThe **FIFA Young Player Award** ("Best Young Player Award" 2006–2010) was awarded for the first time at the [2006 World Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") in Germany and given to Germany\'s [Lukas Podolski](/wiki/Lukas_Podolski "Lukas Podolski").[[64]](#cite_note-podolski-77) The award is given to the best player in the tournament who is at most 21 years old. For the [2022 World Cup](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup"), this meant that the player had to have been born on or after 1 January 2001.\n\nIn 2006,[[65]](#cite_note-78) the election took place on FIFA\'s official World Cup website with the help of The FIFA Technical Study Group.[[66]](#cite_note-79)\n\nFIFA organised a survey on the Internet for users to choose the "Best Young Player" of the World Cup, between 1958 and 2002, named the best young player of each tournament.[[67]](#cite_note-80) With 61% of the overall vote, the winner was [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9 "Pelé"), who finished ahead of the [Peruvian](/wiki/Peru "Peru") [Teófilo Cubillas](/wiki/Te%C3%B3filo_Cubillas "Teófilo Cubillas"), the best young player at [Mexico 1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World Cup"), and England\'s [Michael Owen](/wiki/Michael_Owen "Michael Owen"), who reached similar heights at [France 98](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup").[[68]](#cite_note-81)[[69]](#cite_note-82)\n\nThe winner of the award has only been part of the winning country three times. [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9 "Pelé") in [1958](/wiki/1958_FIFA_World_Cup "1958 FIFA World Cup"), [Kylian Mbappé](/wiki/Kylian_Mbapp%C3%A9 "Kylian Mbappé") in [2018](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup"), and [Enzo Fernández](/wiki/Enzo_Fern%C3%A1ndez "Enzo Fernández") in [2022](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup").\n\n| World Cup | FIFA Young Player | Age | Position |\n| --- | Cup") | [Flórián Albert](/wiki/Fl%C3%B3ri%C3%A1n_Albert "Flórián Albert") | 20 | Centre-Forward |\n| [1966 England](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup "1966 FIFA World Cup") | [Franz France](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup") | [Michael Owen](/wiki/Michael_Owen "Michael Owen") | 18 | Centre-Forward |\n| [2002 South Korea/Japan](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") | [Landon Donovan](/wiki/Landon_Donovan "Landon Donovan") | 20 | Second-Striker |\n| [2006 Germany](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") | [Lukas Podolski](/wiki/Lukas_Podolski "Lukas Podolski")[[64]](#cite_note-podolski-77) | 21 | Second-Striker |\n| [2010 South Africa](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup") | [Thomas Müller](/wiki/Thomas_M%C3%BCller "Thomas Müller")[[70]](#cite_note-83) | 20 | Second-Striker |\n| [2014 Brazil](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup") | [Paul Pogba](/wiki/Paul_Pogba "Paul Pogba")[[71]](#cite_note-84) | 21 | Centre-Midfielder |\n| [2018 Russia](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") | [Kylian Mbappé](/wiki/Kylian_Mbapp%C3%A9 "Kylian Mbappé")[[72]](#cite_note-85) | 19 | Left-Winger |\n| [2022 Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") | [Enzo Fernández](/wiki/Enzo_Fern%C3%A1ndez "Enzo Fernández") | 21 | Centre-Midfielder |\n\n## FIFA Fair Play Trophy\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: FIFA Fair Play Trophy")]\n\n"FIFA World Cup Fair Play Trophy" redirects here. For the women\'s award, see [FIFA Women\'s World Cup Fair Play Trophy](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_Fair_Play_Trophy "FIFA Women\'s World Cup Fair Play Trophy").\n\nThe **FIFA Fair Play Trophy** is given to the team with the best record of [fair play](/wiki/Sportsmanship "Sportsmanship") during the World Cup final tournament since 1970. Only teams that qualified for the second round are considered. The winners of this award earn the FIFA Fair Play Trophy, a diploma, a fair play medal for each player and official, and $50,000 worth of football equipment to be used for youth development.[[73]](#cite_note-86)\n\nThe appearance of the award was originally a certificate. From 1982 to 1990, it was a golden trophy based on [Sport Billy](/wiki/Sport_Billy "Sport Billy"), a football-playing cartoon character from 1982 who became an icon for FIFA Fair play.[[74]](#cite_note-87)[[75]](#cite_note-88) Ever since 1994, it is simply a trophy with an elegant footballer figure.[[76]](#cite_note-89) [Peru](/wiki/Peru_national_football_team "Peru national football team") was the first nation to win the award after receiving no yellow or red cards in the [1970 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World Cup") held in Mexico.[[77]](#cite_note-90)\n\n| World Cup | FIFA Fair Play Trophy winners |\n| --- | --- |\n| [1970 Mexico](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World Cup") | "Germany national football team") |\n| [1978 Argentina](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World Cup") | [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team") |\n| Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") | [England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football team") |\n\n## Player of the Match\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Player of the Match")]\n\nThe **[Player of the Match](/wiki/Player_of_the_Match "Player of the Match")** (POTM) award picks the outstanding player in every match of the tournament. The award was introduced with the name "Man of the Match" in 2002. It was rechristened "Player of the Match" in 2022.\n\nWhile the inaugural two editions were chosen by the technical group,[[78]](#cite_note-91)[[79]](#cite_note-92) since 2010, Player of the Match is picked by an online poll on FIFA\'s website.[[80]](#cite_note-93)[[81]](#cite_note-94)[[82]](#cite_note-95)\n\n| World Cup | Player(s) with most POTM wins | Wins |\n| --- | --- | --- |\n| [2002 South Korea/Japan](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") | [Rivaldo](/wiki/Rivaldo "Rivaldo") | 3 |\n| [2006 Germany](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") | [Andrea Pirlo](/wiki/Andrea_Pirlo "Andrea Pirlo") | 3 |\n| [2010 South Africa](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup") | [Wesley Sneijder](/wiki/Wesley_Sneijder "Wesley Sneijder") | 4 |\n| [2014 Brazil](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup") | [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi") | 4 |\n| [2018 Russia](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") | [Antoine Griezmann](/wiki/Antoine_Griezmann "Antoine Griezmann") [Eden Hazard](/wiki/Eden_Hazard "Eden Hazard") [Harry Kane](/wiki/Harry_Kane "Harry Kane") [Luka Modrić](/wiki/Luka_Modri%C4%87 "Luka Modrić") | |\n\n## Most Entertaining Team\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Most Entertaining Team")]\n\nThe **Most Entertaining Team** award is a subjectively awarded prize for the team that had done the most to entertain the public with a positive approach to the game, organised through public participation in a poll[[7]](#cite_note-FIFA_Awards-7) starting in 1994.[[43]](#cite_note-glance-43)\n\n| World Cup | Most Entertaining Team Award |\n| --- | --- |\n| [1994 United States](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup") | [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team")[[57]](#cite_note-FIFA.com-65) |\n| [1998 France](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup") | [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football team")[[57]](#cite_note-FIFA.com-65) |\n| [2002 South Korea/Japan](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") | [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea national football team")[[83]](#cite_note-96) |\n| [2006 Germany](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") | [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team "Portugal national football team")[[84]](#cite_note-97) |\n\n## All-Star Team\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: All-Star Team")]\n\n### Official winners (1994–2006)\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Official winners (1994–2006)")]\n\nThe **All-Star Team** is a team of the best performers at the respective World Cup finals. Since 1994, FIFA decided to add official best squads, chosen by its Technical Study Group under the brand name *[MasterCard](/wiki/MasterCard "MasterCard") All-Star Team*.[[85]](#cite_note-94team-98) For 1998, 2002 and 2006, substitute and reserve members were also nominated for full squads.\n\nAll-Star Team\n\n| World Cup | Goalkeepers | Defenders | Midfielders | Forwards | Reserves |\n| [1994 United States](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup")[[85]](#cite_note-94team-98) | [Michel Preud\'homme](/wiki/Michel_Preud%27homme "Michel Preud\'homme") | [Francesco Totti](/wiki/Francesco_Totti "Francesco Totti") | — |\n\n### Other selections\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Other selections")]\n\nMany different newspapers, sports journalists, managers and former players have picked their All-Star teams for the tournaments over the years. Newspapers which picked their All-Star teams include *[Sport-Magazin](/wiki/Kicker_(sports_magazine) "Kicker (sports magazine)"), Mundo Esportivo, [France Football](/wiki/France_Football "France Football")*, [Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press"), *Estadio, [El Gráfico](/wiki/El_Gr%C3%A1fico_(Argentina) "El Gráfico (Argentina)"), Goles, [Guerin Sportivo](/wiki/Guerin_Sportivo "Guerin Sportivo"), Crónica, [El Mercurio](/wiki/El_Mercurio "El Mercurio"), La Prensa, [Clarín](/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper) "Clarín (Argentine newspaper)"), [La Razón](/wiki/La_Raz%C3%B3n_(Buenos_Aires) "La Razón (Buenos Aires)"), [El País](/wiki/El_Pa%C3%ADs_(Uruguay) "El País (Uruguay)"), [L\'Équipe](/wiki/L%27%C3%89quipe "L\'Équipe"), [Mundo Deportivo](/wiki/Mundo_Deportivo "Mundo Deportivo"), [De Volkskrant](/wiki/De_Volkskrant "De Volkskrant"), [La Gazzetta dello Sport](/wiki/La_Gazzetta_dello_Sport "La Gazzetta dello Sport"), [Don Balón](/wiki/Don_Bal%C3%B3n "Don Balón"), [La Stampa](/wiki/La_Stampa "La Stampa"), [Kicker](/wiki/Kicker_(sports_magazine) "Kicker (sports magazine)"), Deporte Gráfico, Spotivo Sur, [Match](/wiki/Match_(magazine) "Match (magazine)"), Fußball Woche, [Placar](/wiki/Placar "Placar"), [Shoot!](/wiki/Shoot_(football_magazine) "Shoot (football magazine)")*, [BBC Sport](/wiki/BBC_Sport "BBC Sport"), *[Süddeutsche Zeitung](/wiki/S%C3%BCddeutsche_Zeitung "Süddeutsche Zeitung"), [Diario AS](/wiki/Diario_AS "Diario AS")* and [*Marca*](/wiki/Marca_(newspaper) "Marca (newspaper)").\n\nSports journalists, managers and former players who picked their All-Star teams include Dr. Friedebert Becker, [Gabriel Hanot](/wiki/Gabriel_Hanot "Gabriel Hanot"), [Enzo Bearzot](/wiki/Enzo_Bearzot "Enzo Bearzot"), [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9 "Pelé"), [Roberto Bettega](/wiki/Roberto_Bettega "Roberto Bettega"), [Eugenio Bersellini](/wiki/Eugenio_Bersellini "Eugenio Bersellini"), [Giovanni Trapattoni](/wiki/Giovanni_Trapattoni "Giovanni Trapattoni"), [Massimo Giacomini](/wiki/Massimo_Giacomini "Massimo Giacomini"), [Sandro Mazzola](/wiki/Sandro_Mazzola "Sandro Mazzola"), Paolo Carosi, [Jimmy Greaves](/wiki/Jimmy_Greaves "Jimmy Greaves"), [Pichi Alonso](/wiki/Pichi_Alonso "Pichi Alonso") and [Johan Cruyff](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff "Johan Cruyff").\n\nSince the beginning many newspapers gave players points to players based on their performances at the World Cup. Some are based in statistics, but some were just rankings given by experts.[[89]](#cite_note-102) [Castrol Football](/wiki/Castrol_performance_index "Castrol performance index") has given retrospective rankings to players until 1966 with their expert panel consisting of people such as [Cristiano Ronaldo](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo "Cristiano Ronaldo"), [Arsène Wenger](/wiki/Ars%C3%A8ne_Wenger "Arsène Wenger"), [Marcel Desailly](/wiki/Marcel_Desailly "Marcel Desailly"), [Cafu](/wiki/Cafu "Cafu"), [Alan Shearer](/wiki/Alan_Shearer "Alan Shearer"), [Emilio Butragueño](/wiki/Emilio_Butrague%C3%B1o "Emilio Butragueño"), [Ronald Koeman](/wiki/Ronald_Koeman "Ronald Koeman"), [Pierluigi Collina](/wiki/Pierluigi_Collina "Pierluigi Collina"), [Ottmar Hitzfeld](/wiki/Ottmar_Hitzfeld "Ottmar Hitzfeld"), [Gary Bailey](/wiki/Gary_Bailey "Gary Bailey"), [Peter Stöger](/wiki/Peter_St%C3%B6ger "Peter Stöger"), [Mohamed Al-Deayea](/wiki/Mohamed_Al-Deayea "Mohamed Al-Deayea") and [Stanislav Levý](/wiki/Stanislav_Lev%C3%BD "Stanislav Levý").[[90]](#cite_note-103)\n\nThere are rumours about "official" World Cup All-Star teams across the internet. The same teams have been published on many websites including [football.sporting99.com](https://football.sporting99.com/fifa-world-cup-all-star-team.html), [worldcupbrazil.net](https://web.archive.org/web/20200211160635/http://www.worldcupbrazil.net/world-cup-history/), [talksport](/wiki/Talksport "Talksport")[[91]](#cite_note-104) and [thesoccerworldcups.com](https://www.thesoccerworldcups.com/world_cups.php). It is unclear where these teams originated, but the earliest they can be found on the internet was in the October of 2011 on the football.sporting99.com website.[[92]](#cite_note-105)\n\n#### 1930 Uruguay\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: 1930 Uruguay")]\n\nSelections by medium\n\n| Medium | Goalkeeper | Defenders | Midfielders | Forwards Monti](/wiki/Luis_Monti "Luis Monti") [José Leandro Andrade](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Leandro_Andrade "José Leandro Andrade") | [Pedro Cea](/wiki/Pedro_Cea "Pedro Cea") [Manuel |\n\n#### Unofficial winners (1990 Italy)\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Unofficial winners (1990 Italy)")]\n\nIn 1990, there was an All-Star Team announced in combination with the Golden Ball ceremony. It was chosen by the same journalists who chose the best player, but this team is still considered unofficial.[[140]](#cite_note-153)[[141]](#cite_note-BigSoccer-deadlink-154)\n\nUnofficial All-Star Team\n\n| Goalkeeper | Defenders | Midfielders | Forwards | Reserves |\n| [Cláudio Taffarel](/wiki/Cl%C3%A1udio_Taffarel "Cláudio Taffarel") | [Jorginho](/wiki/Jorginho_(footballer,_born_1964) "Jorginho (footballer, born 1964)") [Giuseppe Bergomi](/wiki/Giuseppe_Bergomi "Giuseppe Bergomi") [Franco Baresi](/wiki/Franco_Baresi "Franco Baresi") [Guido Buchwald](/wiki/Guido_Buchwald "Guido Buchwald") [Andreas Brehme](/wiki/Andreas_Brehme "Andreas Brehme") | [Roberto Donadoni](/wiki/Roberto_Donadoni "Roberto Donadoni") [Lothar Matthäus](/wiki/Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us "Lothar Matthäus") [Enzo Scifo](/wiki/Enzo_Scifo "Enzo Scifo") | [Salvatore Schillaci](/wiki/Salvatore_Schillaci "Salvatore Schillaci") [Jürgen Klinsmann](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Klinsmann "Jürgen Klinsmann") | [Gabelo Conejo](/wiki/Gabelo_Conejo "Gabelo Conejo") [Branco](/wiki/Branco_(footballer) "Branco (footballer)") [Des Walker](/wiki/Des_Walker "Des Walker") [Dragan Stojković](/wiki/Dragan_Stojkovi%C4%87 "Dragan Stojković") [Roger Milla](/wiki/Roger_Milla "Roger Milla") |\n\n#### Statistical winners (2010–2018)\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Statistical winners (2010–2018)")]\n\nAfter FIFA changed its sponsor from MasterCard to [Visa](/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc.") in 2007,[[142]](#cite_note-155) it published Team of the Tournament based on statistical data of other sponsors, which evaluates players\' performances. FIFA explained these are not official.[[143]](#cite_note-fantasy-156)\n\nStatistical Team of the Tournament\n\n| World Cup | Standard | Goalkeeper | Defenders | Midfielders | Forwards |\n| [2010 South Dream Team (2010–2018)")]\n\nSince 2010, the *Fan Dream Team* has been voted by online poll of FIFA website, but FIFA explained this is also not official team.[[143]](#cite_note-fantasy-156)\n\nFan Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi") |\n\n## Goal of the Tournament\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Goal of the Tournament")]\n\nThe **Goal of the Tournament** award was awarded for the first time at the [2006 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup").\n\n* Scores and results list the goal tally of the players\' team first.\n\n### Official winners\n\n[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_awards&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Official winners")]\n\n| World Cup | Player | Scored against | Rodríguez](/wiki/Maxi_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Maxi Rodríguez") | [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football team") | **2**–1 | [Business Wire](/wiki/Business_Wire "Business Wire"). 17 July 1994. [FIFA] has announced Oleg Salenko (Russia) and Hristo Stoichkov (Bulgaria) as [...] winners of the prestigious adidas Golden Shoe award [...] who made six goals and one assist each. Kennet Andersson (Sweden) with 5 goals and 3 assists, will receive a Bronze replica of the Predator [...] Throughout World Cup \'94, three points were awarded for each goal scored and one point for each assist leading to a goal, with a maximum of two assists per goal. Assists are only taken into account if two or more players scored the same number of goals.\n53. **[^](#cite_ref-58)** ["1994 FIFA World Cup Technical Report"](https://web.archive.org/web/20100106062745/http://www.fifa.com/mm/document/afdeveloping/technicaldevp/50/08/58/wc%5f94%5ftr%5fpart2%5f271.pdf) (PDF). [Jerković](/wiki/Dra%C5%BEan_Jerkovi%C4%87 "Dražan Jerković"), [Sánchez](/wiki/Leonel_S%C3%A1nchez "Leonel Sánchez") & [Vavá](/wiki/Vav%C3%A1 "Vavá") * **[1966](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup "1966 FIFA World Cup"):** [Eusébio](/wiki/Eus%C3%A9bio "Eusébio") * **[1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World Cup"):** [G. Müller](/wiki/Gerd_M%C3%BCller "Gerd Müller") * **[1974](/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup "1974 FIFA World Cup"):** [Lato](/wiki/Grzegorz_Lato "Grzegorz Lato") * **[1978](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World Cup"):** [Kempes](/wiki/Mario_Kempes "Mario Kempes") |\n| Golden Shoe | * **[1982](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World Cup"):** [Rossi](/wiki/Paolo_Rossi "Paolo Rossi") * **[1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup"):** [Lineker](/wiki/Gary_Lineker "Gary Lineker") * **[1990](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup "1990 FIFA World Cup"):** [Schillaci](/wiki/Salvatore_Schillaci "Salvatore Schillaci") * **[1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup"):** [Salenko](/wiki/Oleg_Salenko "Oleg Salenko") & [Stoichkov](/wiki/Hristo_Stoichkov "Hristo Stoichkov") * **[1998](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup"):** [Šuker](/wiki/Davor_%C5%A0uker "Davor Šuker") * **[2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup"):** [Ronaldo](/wiki/Ronaldo_(Brazilian_footballer) "Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)") * **[2006](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup"):** [Klose](/wiki/Miroslav_Klose "Miroslav Klose") |\n| Golden Boot | * **[2010](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup"):** [T. Müller](/wiki/Thomas_M%C3%BCller "Thomas Müller") * **[2014](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup"):** [Rodríguez](/wiki/James_Rodr%C3%ADguez "James Rodríguez") * Hilal](/soccer/story/_/id/45933239/liverpool-darwin-nunez-transfer-al-hilal)\n\n7hESPN News Services\n\n[Son makes instant impact, wins PK on LAFC debut](/soccer/story/_/id/45935038/son-heung-min-lafc-debut-chicago-fire-penalty)\n\n7hESPN\n\n# How Argentina won the 2022 World Cup, in their own words\n\n* Alex KirklandDec 18, 2023, 07:00 AM ET\n\n* [Copy Link](#)\n* [Email](mailto:?subject=How%20Argentina%20won%20the%202022%20World%20Cup,%20in%20their%20own%20words&body=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.espn.com%2Fsoccer%2Fstory%2F_%2Fid%2F39121682)\n* [Print](https://www.espn.com/espn/print?id=39121682)\n\nOn Dec. 18, 2022, [Argentina](/soccer/team?id=202) won the men\'s [World Cup](/soccer/league/_/name/FIFA.WORLD) in the most dramatic way possible, beating [France](/soccer/team?id=478) in a penalty shootout after a breathless 3-3 draw in Lusail, Qatar.\n\nThe game was an instant classic, one of the best finals anyone could remember, packed with unforgettable moments. [Lionel Messi](/soccer/player/_/id/45843/lionel-messi) delivered on the biggest stage of all, exorcising the ghosts of his 2014 heartbreak when Argentina were beaten in the World Cup final in Brazil. France\'s [Kylian Mbappé](https://www.espn.co.uk/football/player/_/id/231388/kylian-mbappe) scored a hat trick but still ended up on the losing side. Argentina goalkeeper [Emiliano Martínez](/soccer/player/_/id/158626/emiliano-martinez) starred with a jaw-dropping, last-gasp added-time stop from France\'s [Randal Kolo Muani](/soccer/player/_/id/252971/randal-kolo-muani) before saving twice in the decisive shootout.\n\nThe win gave Argentina a third World Cup winners\' star on their shirts, following victories in 1978 and 1986. Only Brazil (with five), Italy (four) and Germany (four) have more. It also helped Messi live up to the legacy of the football-obsessed country\'s other great hero -- and architect of their 1986 triumph -- Diego Maradona.\n\nThe drama of the final was a fitting end to Argentina\'s roller-coaster ride through the tournament. It started with a surprise 2-1 opening defeat to [Saudi Arabia](/soccer/team?id=655), bouncing back with nail-biting group-stage victories against [Mexico](/soccer/team?id=203) and [Poland](/soccer/team?id=471), and then knockout stage wins over [Australia](/soccer/team?id=628), [Netherlands](/soccer/team?id=449) -- in another shootout -- and 2018 finalists [Croatia](/soccer/team?id=477).\n\nTo celebrate the first anniversary of Argentina\'s World Cup win, ESPN spoke to 10 members of the squad -- Messi, Martinez, [Ángel Di María](/soccer/player/_/id/108223/angel-di-maria), [Enzo Fernández](/soccer/player/_/id/285450/enzo-fernandez), [Lautaro Martínez](/soccer/player/_/id/219713/lautaro-martinez), [Alexis Mac Allister](/soccer/player/_/id/249299/alexis-mac-allister), [Rodrigo De Paul](/soccer/player/_/id/174466/rodrigo-de-paul), [Nicolás Otamendi](/soccer/player/_/id/119289/nicolas-otamendi), [Julián Álvarez](/soccer/player/_/id/277206/julian-alvarez) and [Cristian Romero](https://www.espn.co.uk/football/player/_/id/96970/cristian-romero) -- for the Star+ series "Champions, One Year On."\n\nThis is their story, in their own words.\n\n---\n\n## The World Cup group stage begins\n\n### Saudi Arabia 2-1 Argentina\n\n*Nov. 22, 2022. The tournament is two days old and already has its first great upset. Messi\'s first-half penalty puts Argentina ahead, before second-half goals from [Saleh Al-Shehri](/soccer/player/_/id/177897/saleh-al-shehri) and [Salem Al-Dawsari](/soccer/player/_/id/163850/salem-al-dawsari) see Saudi Arabia claim an historic win.*\n\n**Lionel Messi:** We were confident in what we were doing, with how we were playing. We were calm. We knew what we had to do. Everything was flowing easily. Nobody thought about that first game, which in theory was the easiest in the group.\n\n**Enzo Fernandez:** We knew how important it was to win that first game. We didn\'t expect [to lose].\n\n**Rodrigo De Paul:** It was really tough. ... With all due respect, we were the favourites [against Saudi Arabia], so it was a huge blow. For two days after that, you were asking yourself, "Why is this happening?"\n\n**Emi Martinez:** What I remember most was going into the dressing room afterwards, obviously devastated. ... I sat down, started taking off my boots and gloves. And you could hear everything. ... I remember the silence.\n\n**Messi:** After the loss, a million things were going through my head. They were difficult days.\n\n**Emi Martinez:** I spoke to my psychologist a lot. I said, "I keep thinking that if we lose against Mexico I\'m going home, and it\'s killing me." I\'d go to sleep, wake up and think about that. ... I said, "I can\'t go back to Argentina in 10 days." Those three days were so long.\n\n**Alexis Mac Allister:** The next day [the coaching staff] let our families come in, to spend some time with them. I think it was important for the group. It isn\'t easy being locked away in a hotel. It was really important to see our families, to pick up some good vibes.\n\n**Messi:** I let that day pass, to forget about what had happened, and then I sent a message to the group. And that\'s when we started to move forward. Everyone said what they thought. We didn\'t have to throw it in each others\' faces. [The defeat] was bad luck. It was about continuing to believe in what we\'d been doing. We couldn\'t start to doubt. We didn\'t have to change anything. We just had to forget about what had happened and start from scratch. Because if we won both games, we\'d top the group.\n\n**Fernandez:** That showed the strength of the group, the unity we had. We were all pulling in the same direction. ... After the Saudi Arabia game, they were all finals. We said that. All or nothing. We had a meeting, and said that from the second game on, they were all finals for us. That\'s how we felt, and that\'s how we played.\n\n---\n\n### Argentina 2-0 Mexico\n\n*Nov. 26, 2022. Coach Lionel Scaloni makes five changes to the team beaten by Saudi Arabia. After a tense first hour, Messi breaks the deadlock, shooting low into the bottom corner from outside the box, before later providing the assist for substitute Fernandez\'s first international goal. Argentina aren\'t going home yet.*\n\n**Messi:** It was hard, playing against Mexico. They\'re always a difficult opponent. We\'ve played them a lot of times, and we almost always win, but it\'s always difficult.\n\n**Emi Martinez:** Half-time in the Mexico game was intense. We weren\'t sure of what we were doing, we weren\'t ourselves. There were a lot of nerves.\n\n**Alvarez:** I was on the bench, and I don\'t think I\'ve ever been so scared. I\'ve never felt such fear. We were this close to being out of the World Cup in the second game.\n\n**Fernandez:** Whether we stayed at the World Cup or not depended on that result. We knew it was an important game in terms of morale, and luckily we were able to win. Leo [Messi] appeared with that magic left foot.\n\n**Messi:** After that goal, the team started to play as we had been doing. A weight was lifted. And it was a different game. We knew the World Cup was starting again. The Mexico game was the departure point.\n\n**Nicolas Otamendi:** That\'s where we loosened up. For me it was one of the most important games at the World Cup. We had to win, at all costs, to not depend on other results.\n\n**De Paul:** In the first half, things hadn\'t gone well -- quite the opposite. But that day, the only one who could make us win was the No. 10. And he did. Again.\n\nDoes Lionel Messi expect to play at the 2026 World Cup?\n\nLionel Messi reveals his future plans with the Argentina national team, a year on from their World Cup success.\n\n---\n\n### Argentina 2-0 Poland\n\n*Nov. 30, 2022. This time, there\'s no drama. Mac Allister and Alvarez -- now established as starters, alongside Fernandez -- both score in a 2-0 win, which means Argentina qualify for the round of 16 as group winners.*\n\n**Emi Martinez:** I knew that we were going to steamroller Poland. They just sent long balls up to [Robert] Lewandowski. When teams sit deep, we move the ball around, and it\'s hard [for them] to keep a clean sheet. In every game, teams sit deep, and we always find a goal.\n\n**Messi:** We respect all our opponents. After what happened with Saudi Arabia, even more so. But we\'d studied Poland. If we were on form, we\'d beat them easily.\n\n**Mac Allister:** After Poland, it became a battle to the death. I\'m not saying we felt like champions, but we were very optimistic that we could do it.\n\n*At 2-0, one moment catches the eye: an on-field clash between Messi and Poland\'s Lewandowski. Messi had previously praised Lewandowski, saying he deserved to win the 2020 Ballon d\'Or when it was cancelled because of the COVID-19 pandemic. He had since been angered by Lewandowski\'s apparent suggestion that those comments were insincere.*\n\n*Messi appears to deliberately dribble at Lewandowski, taking him on, and then shrug off an attempted handshake from the forward.*\n\n**Messi:** What [Lewandowski] had said annoyed me. When I won the Ballon d\'Or, and said what I said, I meant it. And for him to say what he said ... it annoyed me. Later on we met, we spoke and it was a misunderstanding. ... I dribbled at him because it was him. I was annoyed. I thought what he said wasn\'t right. I was angry.\n\n**Di Maria:** I saw it, you saw it, my grandmother saw it. That\'s just what [Messi] is like. ... Sometimes he keeps things bottled up inside. And then he ends up throwing it in your face in an interview, or doing it to you on the football field. That\'s his way of talking, and I think it\'s normal. There are people who talk, and don\'t respect him, and don\'t realize he\'s the best player of all time.\n\nYou shouldn\'t say anything to him. In the end, he gets fired up, and it\'s worse.\n\n---\n\n## Argentina enters the World Cup knockout stage\n\n### Argentina 2-1 Australia\n\n*Dec. 3, 2022. The round of 16. Argentina face Australia, who finished second -- level on points with France -- in Group D. Messi puts them ahead with his third goal of the tournament, pouncing on a loose ball inside the box, and Alvarez makes it 2-0.*\n\n**Lionel Messi:** I got the ball by chance. Ota[mendi] tried to control it. He saw me and he stopped. I tried to take it quickly, there wasn\'t much space inside the box. I was close [to goal] and the keeper reacted late, because he didn\'t expect it. It was a nice moment.\n\n*A late own goal from Fernandez gives Australia hope, and keeper Martinez is needed to make a smart save in the last seconds of added time from substitute [Garang Kuol](/soccer/player/_/id/332947/garang-kuol).*\n\n**Emi Martinez:** When [Kuol] controlled the ball, I saw that Nico [Otamendi] couldn\'t help me. He controlled it so well that I had to go and deal with it. ... [After making the save] Everyone hugged me except Cuti [Romero], who kicked me in the ribs. Typical Cuti. That\'s his way of showing love.\n\n---\n\n### Argentina 2-2 Netherlands (4-3 penalties)\n\n*Dec. 9, 2022. The quarterfinals are next, and after an injury scare in the days leading up to the game, influential midfielder De Paul is cleared to play. Four hours before Argentina\'s quarterfinal with Netherlands is due to kick off in Lusail, archrivals Brazil are playing Croatia.*\n\n**Messi:** We left the hotel when Brazil went 1-0 up. When we were getting close to the stadium, [Croatia] scored the equaliser. In the dressing room, I was getting a massage and the penalty shootout started. I was on my phone. Kun [Aguero] was telling me about the penalties. I was face-down on the bed, reading his messages.\n\n**Fernandez:** We were watching the shootout. I remember when Brazil were eliminated, we were shouting, happy, and Scaloni comes in saying, "What are you doing, you idiots? We have to play a game now!" The game with Netherlands was 10 minutes away, and we were there celebrating in the dressing room. But it was good for our morale.\n\n*Argentina vs. Netherlands turns out to be spectacularly bad-tempered. A World Cup record 18 yellow cards are shown by referee Antonio Mateu Lahoz -- eight for the Dutch, eight for Argentina and two for Scaloni and his assistant, Walter Samuel -- as well as a late red card for Netherlands defender [Denzel Dumfries](/soccer/player/_/id/213248/denzel-dumfries).*\n\n**Alexis Mac Allister:** They started it.\n\n**Nicolas Otamendi:** We can mix it with the best of them.\n\n**Messi:** I get annoyed when people talk off the pitch, and show a lack of respect. I\'ve never been like that. On the pitch, a million things can happen, but it stays there. Before the game, stirring things up or lacking respect, I\'ve never done that, and I don\'t like it when people do it to me ... I didn\'t like that.\n\n*Messi is again the inspiration for Argentina, setting up Molina\'s first-half opener before converting a penalty. He celebrates by cupping his ears in front of the Dutch bench.*\n\n**Otamendi:** We didn\'t know Leo was going to do that. I think it just came out in the heat of the moment. But they\'d done a lot of talking.\n\n**Messi:** I did it in the moment. And I regretted it straight away. As soon as I did it, I thought, "What an idiot. ... All that\'s missing now is that we don\'t win." These things happen.\n\n*From 2-0 down, Netherlands fight back. Forward [Wout Weghorst](/soccer/player/_/id/177042/wout-weghorst) scores twice, making it 2-2 in the 11th minute of added time after receiving the ball from a clever free kick, slipping underneath Argentina\'s defensive wall. Goalkeeper Emi Martinez recovers to become the hero in Argentina\'s first shootout of the tournament, saving the first two Dutch spot kicks from [Virgil van Dijk](/soccer/player/_/id/157892/virgil-van-dijk) and [Steven Berghuis](/soccer/player/_/id/149577/steven-berghuis).*\n\n*Argentina\'s decisive fifth penalty is scored by substitute Lautaro Martinez.*\n\n**Lautaro Martinez:** I was going to shoot hard and to the right. And I don\'t know why I paused [my run-up]. I used to take penalties like that, a long time ago. I missed a couple of penalties and I changed. And in that moment I decided to pause. I saw he was going that way, and I changed my mind.\n\n[The celebration] was about what it meant, how I\'d suffered, how I\'d started the World Cup, how my ankle was, and what it meant to be in the semifinals.\n\nWhat\'s it like to win a World Cup final on penalties?\n\nArgentina\'s players remember how they felt during their penalty shootout win over France in the World Cup final.\n\n---\n\n### Argentina 3-0 Croatia\n\n*Dec. 13, 2022. The semifinals. Argentina beat Croatia 3-0 with another Messi penalty, and a brace from Julian Alvarez.*\n\n**Messi:** We\'d played Croatia at the last World Cup [in 2018] and they scored four against us. But this was different. We knew if we got through, Croatia were beatable.\n\n**Emi Martinez:** The Croatia game was the best all-round game the team played.\n\n*Alvarez\'s first goal is the result of a run that began just inside the Croatia half; his second follows one of the moves of the tournament, a mazy Messi dribble that twists defender [Josko Gvardiol](/soccer/player/_/id/299910/josko-gvardiol) back and forth, before setting up Alvarez for a tap-in.*\n\n**Julian Alvarez:** I think it was my best game for the national team. When I scored the [first] goal, I didn\'t even remember that I\'d started from so far out. Later I watched it. I got a bit of luck, but it\'s a great goal.\n\n**De Paul:** People say that the game against Croatia was easier than against France [in the final] or Netherlands. But the reality is that, over the course of the game, we were just as comfortable in all three games. We were always better.\n\n---\n\n### Argentina 3-3 France (4-2 penalties)\n\n*Dec. 18, 2022. The World Cup final.*\n\n**Alvarez:** I remember talking to Enzo [Fernandez], saying, "We\'re going to play a World Cup final." He was anxious for the game to arrive. But I wasn\'t. I wanted the game to be over. I almost didn\'t want to play.\n\n**Emi Martinez:** My dad was saying do things well, don\'t overplay it, don\'t make mistakes. Everyone was afraid of making a mistake, but I was thinking just the opposite. I\'m going to play like I\'ve played all my life, without fear, with confidence. Whatever happens, I\'m playing a World Cup final.\n\n**Messi:** I didn\'t want to even look at the trophy. They say you don\'t look at it, you don\'t touch it. So I didn\'t, just in case.\n\n*Scaloni -- as he had done throughout the tournament -- tweaks his team again, starting Di Maria on the left wing. Di Maria rewards his manager by providing the final touch to a lightning-quick counterattack, making it 2-0 in the 36th minute after Messi had put Argentina ahead from the penalty spot.*\n\n**Messi:** Our counterattack was amazing. So fast. It was a great goal.\n\n**Di Maria:** It was a spectacular move between three players, with one or two touches, as if they were playing in their neighbourhood. Inexplicable. Incredible.\n\n*Argentina look to be heading for a straightforward win, until two goals in two minutes from Mbappé make it 2-2, forcing extra time.*\n\n**Alvarez:** We played a great game until the 70th minute or something. And then in five minutes, everything changed.\n\n**Messi:** I was angry, because the goal was down to me losing the ball, even if it was halfway up the pitch. It was our ball.\n\n*Messi\'s goal comes in the 108th minute. [Hugo Lloris](/soccer/player/_/id/43372/hugo-lloris) saves Lautaro Martinez\'s shot, and Messi is there to bundle the ball over the line.*\n\n**Lautaro Martinez:** We were celebrating. We hadn\'t seen the assistant referee lift the flag. The bench came to celebrate with us. The referee raised his hand, and we thought it had been disallowed. Then he pointed towards the centre circle, and we celebrated again. We celebrated three times!\n\n**Julian Alvarez:** When we made it 3-2, I said, \'Well that\'s that, nothing else is going to happen.\' We were on the bench, watching the clock. [Angel] Di Maria was crying. And then they scored, and he was still crying.\n\n*Incredibly, that wasn\'t that. In the 116th minute, France are awarded a penalty for a handball, and Mbappé converts to make it 3-3, though there was still time for one more moment of unbearable tension. In the 123rd minute -- seconds from a penalty shootout -- France substitute Kolo Muani finds himself through on goal. His shot is low and powerful, headed for the bottom corner. Emi Martinez sticks out a long leg and makes the save.*\n\n**Mac Allister:** I think I was one of the only ones who reacted. They were all in shock. Nobody could believe it.\n\n**De Paul:** I didn\'t see it, thank God. I was sat down, with ice on my leg. ... I saw [the save] two or three days later. I couldn\'t believe it. It\'s iconic. It\'s a moment that will go down in history.\n\n**Otamendi:** I realised I wasn\'t going to get there [to the ball]. I tried to clear it with my toes. But then the left foot of "the beast" [Martinez] saved it. I think our hearts stopped. ... Argentinians live to suffer. It had to be that way.\n\n**Emi Martinez:** If I come further off my line, he\'d chip me. If I stay on my line, he has the whole goal to aim at. I stayed somewhere in between. He says, "If I control it, he takes it off me, I can\'t go over him, so I\'ll hit it." I leave him that space, and when he hits it, I spread myself and I block it. It could have gone in, if the shot was anywhere else it was a goal. And that\'s luck. I gambled. ... It could have gone in, or not. But it stopped here [pointing at his leg].\n\n*On to penalties. Messi and Mbappé had already taken three between them during the game, scoring all three. They would go first in the shootout, too.*\n\n**Romero:** I kept thinking, "F---. After all that, this can\'t end with a penalty shootout." I remember that Leo took one, and scored. Mbappé scored. After that, I didn\'t see any more. I was on the floor, praying.\n\n**Emi Martinez:** I was calm. I knew that if I saved one, I\'d put pressure on them. [The save from [Kingsley Coman](/soccer/player/_/id/184012/kingsley-coman)] was key. But I made a mistake. I didn\'t save it with my hands. I saved it with my chest, it went through my hands.\n\n**Romero:** Dibu made a save, and I threw myself to the floor. I was on my knees. [Coach] Pablo [Aimar] came over and said, "Get up, get up, don\'t be a coward, watch." But I couldn\'t. I started praying even more. I prayed to God, to all the Saints, to the Virgin.\n\n*After Martinez saves from Coman, France midfielder [Aurélien Tchouaméni](/soccer/player/_/id/265919/aurelien-tchouameni) puts his penalty wide.*\n\n**Emi Martinez:** Look at this guy\'s face and tell me he isn\'t nervous. I could see from the goal that he was dead. And I was thinking that if he missed, they were halfway out and we\'re champions.\n\n*Argentina\'s fourth penalty taker is defender [Gonzalo Montiel](/soccer/player/_/id/228262/gonzalo-montiel). He scores, and Argentina are champions.*\n\n**Messi:** We were calm because Dibu [Martinez] had kept two out. We had more of a chance. I told [Montiel] that it was going to end there, that it was all over.\n\n**Alvarez:** I didn\'t talk to him. But I saw some of my teammates asking whether he was going to take it, if he wanted to, because he didn\'t look so good. I think Lautaro told him he could take the kick, he was fifth. But when "Cache" is determined, he never fails. I think he\'d taken eight or nine penalties before and scored them all. He wasn\'t going to let us down now.\n\n**Romero:** It\'s a moment that stays with you. I achieved the biggest thing a footballer can dream of. I dreamt about this so much. I remembered some beautiful moments, some not so beautiful, what I\'d done to get there. ... Everything goes through your head in five minutes, and you\'re in tears.\n\n**Messi:** I didn\'t sleep with the cup. It was just a photo. We were at the hotel. We had [the trophy] on the bed. We took a couple of photos, and posted them on social media.\n\n---\n\n## After Argentina become World Cup champions\n\n*The focus, of course, is on Messi. Previously, his lack of a World Cup had been held up as proof that he could not aspire to "greatest of all time" status. Not anymore.*\n\n**Messi:** My family had suffered a lot more than me. The joys, as well as the defeats. Putting up with all those years of criticism with the national team. My mum, my dad, my brother, my sister, my nephew who lives in Argentina and grew up there with all that. Always criticism, always killing me. It was a bit like saying, "That\'s it, we did it, the biggest thing there is, the World Cup. That\'s it, it\'s over."\n\n**Fernandez:** I had 500 WhatsApp messages on my phone, easily. Family, friends, acquaintances ... I tried to reply to everyone. It took a while.\n\n**Emi Martinez:** It brought the country together: the rich, the poor, the middle class. That\'s what gave me the most satisfaction.\n\n**Messi:** I knew God wanted me to be world champion, that he was going to give it to me. I always believed in that. There were a lot of big obstacles along the way. I really suffered. I had a bad time. Me, my family, the people who love me. It was very unfair. People said all kinds of things. But I don\'t bear a grudge. With humility and in silence I did my job.\n\nIt\'s a victory for me, having turned that situation around. Winning over the people of Argentina. At times I was questioned. Today 95 or 100% of Argentinians love me, and that\'s beautiful.\n\n*Thoughts soon turn to the future, and whether Messi will stick around to lead this new generation at the next World Cup in 2026.*\n\n**Messi:** Time will tell if I can get to it or not. I\'d be at an age [39] where normally, you wouldn\'t play a World Cup. I said I didn\'t think I\'d be there. It felt like I was retiring after the World Cup and quite the opposite, now I want to be there more than ever. After suffering for so many years, I want to enjoy it ... but with my age, the normal thing would be not to be there. Maybe it goes well at the [Copa America](/soccer/league/_/name/CONMEBOL.AMERICA) and everything is in place to carry on. Maybe not. Being realistic, it\'s difficult.', 'images': []}
item {'url': 'https://www.olympics.com/en/news/fifa-world-cup-2022-results-scores-football', 'raw_content': "# FIFA World Cup 2022: All results, scores and points table\n\nKnow FIFA World Cup 2022 football results and scores from the matches in Qatar. Get group standings and scorecards from the knockout rounds, including final.\n\nPicture by Getty Images\n\nBy Utathya Nag\n\n18 December 2022 19:17 GMT+06 min read\n\nThe [**FIFA World Cup 2022**](https://olympics.com/en/news/fifa-world-cup-2022-live-telecast-streaming-in-india-tv-channels-jio) in Qatar saw a total of 32 top national teams from five different confederations vie for the title of football world champions from November 20 to December 18.\n\nThe 2022 FIFA World Cup followed a familiar format with the 32 teams divided into eight groups - Group A to H - of four teams each. The teams in each group competed in a single-headed round-robin format in the group stage of the competition.\n\nThe groups at the Qatar FIFA World Cup 2022:\n\n**Group A**: Qatar, Ecuador, Senegal, Netherlands\n\n**Group B**: England, Iran, USA, Wales\n\n**Group C**: Argentina, Saudi Arabia, Mexico, Poland\n\n**Group D**: France, Australia, Denmark, Tunisia\n\n**Group E**: Spain, Costa Rica, Germany, Japan\n\n**Group F**: Belgium, Canada, Morocco, Croatia\n\n**Group G**: Brazil, Serbia, Switzerland, Cameroon\n\n**Group H**: Portugal, Ghana, Uruguay, South Korea\n\nAfter the group stage, top two teams from each of the eight groups moved on to the knockout phase, which began with the Round of 16.\n\nThe final was played on December 18 while the third-place match happened on December 17. All matches of the FIFA World Cup 2022 were played across eight [venues](https://olympics.com/en/news/fifa-world-cup-2022-venues-stadiums-qatar-football) in and around Doha.\n\nGet all Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup results, points tables and standings for each group and all scores for the knockout rounds, including the final, here:\n\n## **FIFA World Cup 2022: Results, scores and group stage points table**\n\n[Start 2026 in Italy! Freuler 48')\n\nMatch: Cameroon (Vincent Aboubakar 90+2') 1-0 Brazil\n\n### **FIFA World Cup 2022 Group H points table**\n\nGroup H\n\n| Position | Team | Played | Won | Draw | Loss | Points | GF | GA | GD |\n| 1 | Portugal | 3 | 2 | 0 | 1 | 6 | 6 | 4 | +2 |\n| 2 | South Korea | 3 | 1 | 1 | 1 | 4 | 4 | 4 | 0 |\n| 3 | Uruguay | 3 | 1 | 1 | 1 | 4 | 2 | 2 | 0 |\n| 4 | Ghana | 3 | 1 | 0 | 2 | 3 | 5 | 7 | -2 |\n\n**Group H results and scores**\n\nMatch: Uruguay 0-0 South Korea\n\nMatch: Portugal (Cristiano Ronaldo 65', Joao Felix 78', Rafael Lobo 80') 3-2 Ghana (Andre Ayew 73', Osman Bukari 89')\n\nMatch: South Korea (Cho Gue-sung 58', 61') 2-3 Ghana (Mohammed Salisu 24', Mohammed Kudus 34', 68')\n\nMatch: Portugal (Bruno Fernandes 54', 90+3') 2-0 Uruguay\n\nMatch: Ghana 0-2 Uruguay (Giorgian de Arrascaeta 26', 32')\n\nMatch: South Korea (Kim Young-gwon 27', Hwang Hee-chan 90+1') 2-1 Portugal (Ricardo Horta 5')\n\n\\* Top two teams from each group make the Round of 16\n\nGlossary: GF - Goals For (Goals Scored), GA - Goals Against (Goals Conceded), GD - Goal Difference\n\n### **FIFA World Cup 2022 results: Round of 16 results**\n\n**December 3, Saturday**\n\nNetherlands (Memphis Depay 10', Daley Blind 45+1', Denzel Dumfries 81') 3-1 USA (Haji Wright 76')\n\n**December 4, Sunday**\n\nArgentina (Lionel Messi 35', Julian Alvarez 57') 2-1 Australia (Enzo Fernandez OG 77')\n\nFrance (Olivier Giroud 44', Kylian Mbappe 74', 90+1') 3-1 Poland (Robert Lewandowski 90+9')\n\n**December 5, Monday**\n\nEngland (Jordan Henderson 38', Harry Kane 45+3', Bukayo Saka 57') 3-0 Senegal\n\nJapan (Daizen Maeda 43') 1(1)-1(3) Croatia (Ivan Perisic 55') - penalties\n\n**December 6, Tuesday**\n\nBrazil (Vinicius Jr 7', Neymar 13', Richarlison 29', Paqueta 36') 4-1 South Korea (Palik Seung-ho 76')\n\nMorocco 0(3)-0(0) vs Spain - penalties\n\n**December 7, Wednesday**\n\nPortugal (Gonçalo Ramos 17’, 51’, 67’, Pepe 33’, Raphaël Guerreiro 55’, Rafael Leão 90+2’) 6-1 Switzerland (Manuel Akanji 58')\n\n### **FIFA World Cup 2022 results: Quarter-finals results**\n\n**Quarter-final 1**: December 9, Friday\n\nCroatia (Bruno Petković 116’) 1(4)-1(2) Brazil (Neymar 105+1’) - penalties\n\n**Quarter-final 2**: December 10, Saturday\n\nNetherlands (Wout Weghorst 83’, 90+11’) 2(3)-2(4) Argentina (Nahuel Molina 35’, Lionel Messi 73’(P)) - penalties\n\n**Quarter-final 3**: December 10, Saturday\n\nMorocco (Youssef En-Nesyri 42') 1-0 Portugal\n\n**Quarter-final 4**: December 11, Sunday\n\nEngland (Harry Kane 54’(P)) 1-2 France (Aurélien Tchouaméni 17’, Olivier Giroud 78’)\n\n### **FIFA World Cup 2022 results: Semi-finals results**\n\n**Semi-final 1**: December 14, Wednesday\n\nArgentina (Lionel Messi 34’(P), Julian Alvarez 39’, 69’) 3-0 Croatia\n\n**Semi-final 2**: December 15, Thursday\n\nFrance (Theo Hernández 5’, Randal Kolo Muani 79’) 2-0 Morocco\n\n### **FIFA World Cup 2022 results: Third-place playoff result**\n\n**3rd place playoff**: December 17, Saturday\n\nCroatia (Josko Gvardiol 7', Mislav Orsic 42') 2-1 Morocco (Achraf Dari 9')\n\n### **FIFA World Cup 2022 results: Final result**\n\n**Final**: December 18, Sunday\n\nArgentina (Lionel Messi 23' (P), 108', Angel Di María 36') 3(4)-3(2) France (Kylian Mbappe 80' (P), 81', 118' (P)) - penalties\n\n[20 November - 18 December 2022Football | World Cup 2022 | Qatar\xa0 | Qatar](https://www.olympics.com/en/sport-events/2022-fifa-football-world-cup-qatar/)", 'images': []}
